title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

Alan McConnell, , admitted the offence when he appeared in Ayr Sherf Court. McConnell was drinking at home with his partner on December  last year. But at some point he left the address, in Prestwick’s Raith Avenue, said depute fiscal Lindzi Bayne. His partner went looking for him at a nearby corner shop, but he had driven off so shop staff contacted police. McConnell’s car was traced to Drongan, and he admitted he had driven there. The charge against him stated he drove on roads between Raith Avenue, Prestwick and Coronation Road, Drongan. A breath test revealed  microgrammes of alcohol in  millilitres of breath. The legal limit in Scotland is  microgrammes. The court heard that McConnell had been ‘just over’ the limit in an earlier drink-driving conviction. Defence lawyer John Gallagher said his client was well aware he could be sent to jail this time. However, he made a plea for a sentence of unpaid work on his client, now of Lane Crescent, Drongan. Sherf John Montgomery told McConnell: “You were driving at five times over the prescribed limit. “If you ever offend again like this, it is inevitable you are going to jail.” He imposed a four-year-driving ban on McConnell, and ordered him to do  hours of unpaid work in the community, within six months. title: retired girvan bank boss admits
story: NewsRetired Girvan bank boss admits drink-driving offencesNeighbours had seen William Fairbairn drinking in his garage before driving, Ayr Sherf Court heard.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsWilliam Fairbairn is disqualied from the roads for three years"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA retired bank manager was lucky not to be jailed after admitting two drink-driving offences. Neighbours had seen William Fairbairn drinking in his garage before driving, Ayr Sherf Court heard. Sherf John Montgomery told him: “That would normally mean a custodial sentence. I note your previously unblemished record.” The sherf instead imposed a fine of pound on Fairbairn, and banned him from driving for three years. Depute fiscal Lynda Carnochan described how an anonymous person phoned police on Tuesday afternoon, August , , around .pm. An hour later, police traced a blue Audi car to Rodney Drive in Girvan, and Fairbairn was still in the vehicle. His speech was slurred, said Ms Carnochan. But due to health problems, he struggled to give a breath test.   However, a blood test revealed he had  milligrammes of alcohol in  millilitres of blood, when the legal limit is  milligrammes. Just two months later, on October , , police on mobile patrol saw Fairbairn driving a Vauxhall Corsa. “They were aware of anonymous reports that he was driving while drinking,” said Ms Carnochan. “They followed him into The Avenue, but he did not stop when police flashed lights at him. He then turned into Rodney Drive, and drove past his own address. However he was eventually stopped.” A breath test was this time successful on Fairbairn. And iot showed  microgrammes of alcohol in  millilitres of breath when the legal limit is  microgrammes. Solicitor Hugh Duncan said Fairbairn had retired from the Bank of Scotland in  on a pension of pound per week.   He used his car to visit his -year-old mother, who is resident in a care home, added the lawyer. “The second matter, within such a short space of time, shows there is an issue with alcohol,” Mr Duncan admitted. “His we tells me his drinking is being curtailed. He was hospitalised with a gallstone, and he suffers from COPD.” Sherf Montgomery fined Fairbairn pound on the first charge, with a  months disqualication. He added an pound fine and a three-year disqualication on the second charge. Fairbairn, of Rodney Drive in Girvan, agreed to pay the pound total within  days. His disqualications will run concurrently, making a total of three years, but the Crown made no move to seize the family cars.

title: south ayrshire council becomes first
story: NewsScottish council becomes first in Europe to offer paid leave to victims of domestic abuseThe policy, adopted today by the local authority, is being hailed as an example to others.ShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsVictims are to receive more support"Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSouth Ayrshire Council has become the first local authority in Europe to offer paid leave to staff who are victims of domestic abuse. The new safe leave policy, unveiled today, will see staff receive up to  days of absence to gain help and support for themselves and their families. It follows a motion from councillors Laura Brennan-Whitefield and Brian McGinley to adopt the bill, which was unanimously backed by the regions  councillors. The leave will support employees to attend medical appointments and counselling, attend legal proceedings, seek safe housing and visit support agencies. Ms Brennan-Whitefield, SNP member for Ayr North, said South Ayrshire was setting an example by implementing the policy. She told the Ayrshire Post : Domestic abuse can affect anyone at any time - it affects both men and women so this in inclusive regardless of gender or sexual orientation.I think that it was unanimously agreed at full council shows that this issue is now on peoples’ radar. Hazel Bingham, manager of South Ayrshire Womens Aid, added: South Ayrshire Councils decision is a massive step in the right direction for people living with domestic abuse and will, I have no doubt, make a long lasting dference for people at a time when they need help most. title: five-star-pupils-take-over-peeblesshire-hotel
story: THE old adage about policemen getting younger didnt used to apply to hotel staff.But anyone visiting Cringletie House Hotel on a Tuesday morning can now be forgiven for feeling that little bit older.A pioneering project between Peebles High Schools home economics department and the boutique hotel near Eddleston is allowing third-year pupils take over the kitchen, restaurant, offices and bedrooms.Initiated by Developing the Young Workforce Borders, it is hoped the five-week-long placement will inspire many into the hospitality and tourism industry.Sara Ward, project manager at DYW Borders, told us: "This initiative will showcase the many opportunities that are available within the hospitality, travel and tourism sector."Tourism is one of the largest growth sectors in the Scottish Borders and pupils will be given the opportunity to develop many transferable skills which in turn can prepare them for making the transition to world of work."The project has been devised as a direct reaction to an unexpected shortfall in hospitality workers from overseas following Brexit.And it is hoped the scheme will also raise the profile of Cringletie as a possible place of employment for local school-leavers.Throughout February and into March, pupils will spend every Tuesday morning shadowing staff.And on their final morning the pupils will operate the hotel and serve up lunch for invited guests, including parents, local business and friends.Jeremy Osborne, general manager at Cringletie, said: ldquoThe Cringletie team had a brilliant response from the pupils and over the next few weeks it will only go from strength to strength."This has to be the way forward to encourage young people in to hospitality and show it is a job that is fun, skilful and there always be one for those who want to get on in le.Although the pilot project has just started this week, home economics teacher Kirsty Williams is delighted with the experience her pupils are enjoying.She said: "We would like to thank Cringletie for affording our students this fabulous opportunity at a time when they are making important decisions about their futures."This programme has opened their eyes to the erse range of career paths available within Hospitality and has enhanced their learning tremendously."

title: supermarket-giant-lidl-eyes-up-move-to-galashiels
story: SUPERMARKET giant Lidl has expressed interest in opening a store in Galashiels.Last month an application was submitted to Scottish Borders Council to allow the sale of food goods at units currently occupied by Carpetright and Currys at Comley Bank Mill Retail Park.And Nectar Asset Management, which put in the plans, says there has been interest from the German discount chain to take over one of the buildings.The application states: "This condition iation is sought due to current market uncertainty and to provide greater flexibility should one or both of the units become vacant in the short to medium term."Carpetright announced their CVAin  and the unit was put on the market via [real estate company] Colliers in May ."No enquiries were received whatsoever except for from Lidl in December."As a result there is a high risk that this unit and potentially the entire park could be become vacant in  when all three leases expire unless the consent is widened."It is therefore anticipated that the units could be combined and occupied by Lidl who are a deep-discount food store operator and have shown interest in the premises."Lidl currently has two stores in the Borders, in Kelso and in Hawick.

title: former-scotland-star-could-have-galashiels-street-named-after-him
story: A STREET in Galashiels could be named after former Scotland footballer John Collins.The towns community council has been asked to come up with a list of suggestions for three unnamed roads at Melrose Gait.And at a meeting on Wednesday night the former Celtic and Hibs star, who is now an ambassador at Gala Fairydean Rovers, was unveiled as one of the options.Chairwoman of the community council Judith Cleghorn said: "Alison Wallace from Scottish Borders Council has been in touch to get our suggestions to name three streets at the Melrose Gait estate."The councillors have come up with some suggestions on who to name the streets after and it would be good to get peoples thoughts."Among the famous names put forward was George Hope Tait ndash a poet and town councillor who is also recognised for his contribution to art, architecture, journalism and authorship in the town.Naming a street after one of Galashiels greatest servants, Bill Lamb, was another idea.Mr Lamb, who died last year, was a local councillor for  years.He held several portfolio posts when the Liberal Democrats were in power at Newtown St Boswells.And community councillor Drew Tulley put forward former local government officer George Knox, who died ten years ago.The former Town Clerk was honoured by Her Majesty the Queen in  when he was awarded the Queens Jubilee Medal and again in , when he was given an MBE for his long service in local government in the region.Mr Tulley said: "I would suggest George Knox as an option because of the work he did for this town."I would have liked to have seen a street named after him in the centre of town."I think it is a shame that he hasnt already got a street named after him in Galashiels."

title: chef-cameron-sheds-more-than-eight-stones
story: A PEEBLES chef left his career creating mouth-watering dishes at an award-winning hotel to fight the war on obesity.When former Head Chef of Cringletie House Hotel Cameron MacMichael hit st lb in April , he squeezed into his chef whites with a  inch waist.Looking in the mirror unhappy at the large reflection staring back at him, he made a decision to turn his le around and his incredible weight loss journey to health and happiness began.Cameron worked under Executive Masterchef Chef Willie Pike MBE, one of Scotlandrsquos top chefs who taught him the secret art of blown sugar.This talent would soon become Cameronrsquos crowning glory, and he was renowned for creating realistic fruits filled with sorbet as the core.Cameron also spent time in the kitchen with famed chef Ivan Day, who is acclaimed as the leading expert on historic cookery in Britain.Cameron told us: ldquoIvan has mentored chefs such as Heston Blumenthal, so I was lucky enough to be given the opportunity to learn from him. The skills I learned from Ivan inspired me to create Outlander themed wedding menus for the hotel.Success continued to grow for the award-winning chef, but so did his waistline, and surrounded by food, it constantly became a battle to control the pounds as they crept on.ldquoI simply didnrsquot want to develop long term health problems, Cameron told the Peeblesshire News.ldquoI wanted to become me again.After trying and struggling with countless diets, Cameron turned to the Cambridge plan in a last ditch attempt to gain control of his weight.It would fast become the best decision he ever made after losing a whopping st lbs in nine short months.Cameron explained: ldquoThe diet was not plain sailing, working in the kitchen I was always tempted to eat the wrong kids of foods constantly."It is so easy to cook a quick fix when yoursquore hungry which is usually deep fried.With a new attitude to food, Cameron says the one-to-one support from consultants is perfect for taking control and managing weight.But what drove this incredibly successful and driven chef to hang up his apron and turn up the gas on a new career as Cambridge Weight Loss Consultant.Cameron explained: ldquoI left the kitchen to join the war on obesity which is linked to causing one out of  deaths in Britain.ldquoMy former Cambridge mentors Mark and Nicola Lafferty said I should consider becoming a consultant."With my own success story, vast knowledge of food and the drive to help others, I was seeing clients within the week I was accredited as a consultant.The former chef may have left the hotel industry, but he is still very much doing what he loves - which is creating new dishes.And he is very excited about the launch of his first cook book.ldquoUsing my knowledge of food, I am creating dishes that are  calories. I want to make meals simple, tasty and fun so even the kids can get involved.Cameron hopes to have his cook book published and available to buy this summer.Askedhe had any regrets leaving le as a hotel chef behind, Cameron replied: ldquoIrsquom still a chef, just not for people who want to be cooked for. I now create dishes for people to cook themselves at home which will hopefully enable them to lead a healthy lestyle and take back control.Cameron is based at Cavalry Park, Peebles and can be contacted via Facebook: Cameron MacMichael Independent Consultant Cambridge Weight Plan.Ends.

title: out-of-school-club-is-quids-in-following-online-draw
story: AN out of school club in Jedburgh is celebrating after becoming the first winners of a Borders businesss first giveaway.The online directory Borders offered a prize of pound through social media to a worthy local cause.Despite entries from across the region it was the Jedburgh Out of School Club that was drawn out of the hat.A spokesman for the club told us: "This is a massive windfall."The much-needed funds will be a substantial help towards outdoor equipment for the children."Joining manager Kelli Wild to collect the winning cheque was parent-helper Lorna Pender, who entered the club into the draw.

title: a-tribute-to-buddy-holly
story: SIXTY years ago on February  , Rock rsquonrsquo Roll lost a legend ndash Buddy Holly. To commemorate the anniversary, tribute show Buddy Holly and The Cricketers are presenting a special performance in venues all over the UK. Tonightthe band will aim to raise the roof of the Eastgate Theatre with songs including all time favourites such as Thatrsquoll Be The Day, Peggy Sue, Heartbeat, It Doesnrsquot Matter Anymore, Raining In My Heart, Oh Boy! He said: ldquoBuddy Holly was pivotal in my development as a guitarist and songwriter.ldquoBuddyrsquos music has touched the hearts of millions around the world and influenced many famous artists such as The Beatles, The Rolling Stones, Eric Clapton, Brian May and many others.ldquoThis year is especially poignant and will be a show to remember.The Buddy Holly and The Cricketers show has been performed for  years and has travelled the world. The show was endorsed as Britainrsquos most popular Buddy Holly act when it appeared on BBC Onersquos The One and Only, with Graham Norton notably commenting that they were ldquoBuddy Brilliant.The show starts at .pm.Ticketsare pound available now from Box Office on   or www.eastgatearts

title: 41-year-old-faces-six-bogus-builder-offences-in-the-borders
story: A -year-old man has appeared in private at Jedburgh Sherf Court accused of six bogus-builder fraud offences.Peter Coyle of Market Street, Duns, also faces a seventh charge of theft.The offences are alleged to have been committed at ious locations in the Borders between January , , and June .He made no plea and the case was continued for further examination.Coyle was released on bail by Sherf Andrew Ferguson with conditions.

title: there-was-an-old-lady-who-swallowed-a-fly-comes-to-the-stage-at-tait-hall-kelso
story: A STAGE version of a much-loved nursery rhyme is coming to Kelso.lsquoThere was an Old Lady who Swallowed a Flyrsquo promises a musical family treat when it arrives in the town next Wednesday.The show, part of Live Bordersrsquo spring  programme, is an adaptation of the comic rhyme telling the tale of a woman who swallows animals.First written as a song in , it was a chart-topping hit for singer and actor, Burl Ives before being adapted into a best-selling book by Pam Adams a few years later.The book is celebrating its th anniversary this year.To mark the occasion, popular childrenrsquos author, Steven Lee has turned the tale into a magical, musical stage show written especially for children to enjoy with their parents.Hamish Moir, programming and events officer at Live Borders said: ldquolsquoThere was an Old Lady who Swallowed a Flyrsquo is an iconic childrenrsquos book and we canrsquot wait to see it performed in the lovely Tait Hall.ldquoAs a charity, we want to see these town halls used for all the community and this is the first in a series of family-centred events coming to our halls in the Borders.The show will be performed by The Peoplersquos Theatre Company at Tait Hall. Doors open at pm, show starts at .pm.Ticketsare pound and can be booked by calling and online from www.liveborders.org.uk. The show is suitable for children aged two and above.

title: cycling-national-park-calls-from-peebles-businessman
story: THE events organiser who brought TweedLove to the Borders is leading calls for the region to become Scotlands first National Park for Cycling.Neil Dalgliesh has helped stage and promote hundreds of two-wheeled events in the area over the past decade.And the closed-road sportives, downhill races and international enduros have boosted the local economy by millions.Now the Peebles-based businessman feels a move to national park status would enhance the regions reputation even further as a cycling destination.He told us: "It was a Scot ndash John Muir - who invented the concept of national parks, and another Scot - Kirkpatrick Macmillan ndash who invented the pedal bicycle, so it seems fitting that we should invent the first National Park for Cycling."We have something internationally unique and extremely valuable right here in the Scottish Borders, and itrsquos the envy of many places around the planet ndash not least just over the border in England."Not only do we have a world class collection of mountain bike trails and off-road tracks, we also have access legislation in Scotland which gives everyone the right to roam on them."Itrsquos also extremely signicant that we have a huge network of quiet tarmac roads through stunning countryside ndash itrsquos an undiscovered road cycling heaven.TweedLoves  events alone produced economic benefit valued at pound, by Scottish Borders Council.While the Tweed Valley - Peebles and Innerleithen in particular - enjoying the financial benefits from cycling, Mr Dalgleish believes national park status would spread the two-wheeled windfall further.He added: "Therersquos a chance to spread that benefit and give recognition to a wider area.ldquoThe areas surrounding the lsquocycling honey potsrsquo are usually overlooked, but have amazing scenery, beautul hill tracks and most importantly some fantastic road cycling to offer.ldquoWe need to be proud of these assets and let the world know what we have to offer."Declaring ourselves a national park for cycling would be big news for cyclists all over the world, but it wouldnrsquot need millions of pounds of investment to deliver.

title: matt-to-pipe-between-the-pages-at-border-libraries
story: TRADITIONAL toe-tapping is coming to a library near you this spring.Borders piper Matt Seattle will be checking into Hawick, Kelso and Galashiels libraries for a series of intimate performances.Matt has performed with a range of international musicians during a successful career.And he also had a starring solo role in the performance by the Scottish Chamber Orchestra of the musical commission for the opening of the Waverley Line.But the performances within the book aisles will be a first - even for Matt.Julia Cawthorne, assistant librarian at Live Borders, told us: ldquoLive Borders Libraries are delighted to be hosting this series of three events in libraries by Matt Seattle."Matt is well respected within the traditional music world and the events promise to be interesting and lively, with each one featuring a dferent selection of tunes for each library venue, Hawick, Galashiels and Kelso.On Thursday, February  at the Hawick Library, Matts performance will feature Walter Ballantyne, Toun Piper of Hawick, The Mystery of the Two Teribus Tunes, and Rattlinrsquo Roarinrsquo Willie of Teviotdale.At the Kelso Library on Tuesday, March , his performance will be John Anderson, My Jo, Toun Piper of Kelso, lsquoAn amourous wag in his dayrsquo and tunes of the Yetholm Gypsies.The finale at Galashiels Library on Thursday, March  features Donald Maclean, Toun Piper of Galashiels, Secrets of the Soor Plums and the Braw Lads.Julia added: "At Live Borders, we believe that libraries play an essential part in the community and we want to encourage audiences to come and see for themselves the wide range of services we have on offer."To book tickets for any of the performances, which all take place between .pm and .pm, call  , email libraries@liveborders.org.uk or visit the host library.

title: innerleithen-to-have-its-say-on-affordable-home-requirements
story: INNERLEITHEN residents are being encouraged to have their say on future housing in the town.Scottish Borders Housing Association will be sending out a survey to all households in the area this month.They want opinion on what is needed in terms of affordable housing in the anonymous questionnaire which will help shape plans for development in the town.Rural Housing Scotland have been commissioned by SBHA to carry out the survey in a bid to engage residents.Chief Executive of Rural Housing Scotland Derek Logie, addressed members of Innerleithen Community Council at a meeting this week.He said: ldquoBy carrying out this survey we want to find out what kind of housing locals feel is needed should theybuild in the future.ldquoWe will be looking attherersquos any new household emerging young people here wanting to leave home. Also people who are living in overcrowded conditions, older people who want to downsize or those who need specialised provision.Askedthis survey was to be carried out where in Tweeddale, Mr Logie said the housing association requested that it was specically Innerleithen.Mr Logie explained: ldquoYou find in the larger communities it is quite easy to demonstrate the need for housing because there are big long waiting lists. In smaller communities where maybe the turnover is less frequent because people donrsquot put their name down so much you have to dig below the surface to find out what is needed.Scottish Borders Councillor Stuart Bell askedthere was a minimum response to have a statistically valid survey.Mr Logie replied: ldquoWe hope to get something like  percent back which tends to be the average. The quantity is not so important, itrsquos the quality in thateverybody that responded said they have housing needs they can respond to that.Councillor Bell stressed that the problem across the Borders is that there is no clear quantication of affordable housing need per community large or small.He added: ldquoI think itrsquos curious and helpful that you are doing this. I was at a meeting of the planning committee and we were sitting looking at a planning application which was focussed on Peebles and we donrsquot know the affordable housing need in Peebles. There isnrsquot a number you can say the demand is X.ldquoThere is evidence of some support, which is that the Chief Executive of Eildon Housing, Nile Istephan said the last time they were advertising properties in Peebles the got  for each property. To a degree that is representative but we donrsquot know what the affordable accommodation need is in not just Peebles, but Walkerburn, Innerleithen and West Linton, which are numbers we ought to know in order for informed decisions to be taken.ldquoIrsquom really pleased yoursquore doing this, Irsquod just like to see it done in other communities also.Residents are being urged to complete the survey which can be completed by hand or electronically. Results will be available mid-March .

title: pet-of-the-week
story: This weeks Pet Of The Week, from Borders Pet Rescue, features a pair of four-year-old Musk Turtles.The charity told us: "They came in to us as their owner sadly passed away. They dont really take much looking after and both seem quite happy and healthy so would make great pets for someone. They must be rehomed together."We have recently moved them into a bigger tank here at the centre with more enrichment and they are showing how active and interesting they can be to watch, so they would need the same type of set up in their new home."If you would like to offer them a forever home, please email info@borderspetrescue.org for an application."

title: breath-of-fresh-air-as-cheyne-gang-turns-one
story: COMMUNITY singing group Tweed Valley Cheyne Gang is celebrating its first birthday.The Innerleithen-based choir was set up last year for people living with long-term respiratory conditions such as COPD , asthma and bronchiectasis.The aim is to encourage singers to use better breathing techniques, undertake a gentle physical workout and have a lot of fun.And the gang has had a busy first year.Not only has it met fortnightly in Innerleithen but, along with the other Cheyne Gang groups in Edinburgh, has performed at Jupiter Artland with The Nevis Ensemble and sung at the Scottish Parliament at the launch of Chest Heart and Stroke Scotlandrsquos report on the need for more rehabilitation servicesThe group has taken part in the Edinburgh Book Festival, raised funds locally through a coffee morning and is currently taking part in research with medical students from Edinburgh University.Voice coach, Julie Harvey has been delighted with the progress of the group.She said:ldquoIt has been a huge privilege to work as a voice coach with The Cheyne Gang over the past  months.ldquoThe Borders group has been a huge success thanks to our amazing singers, our helpers, our local community in Tweeddale and the Cheyne Gang team in Edinburgh.ldquoI believe passionately in the positive impact singing can have on our physical and mental health and well-being, and in our everyday le.ldquoWe have a lot of fun at the Cheyne Gang sessions, but we also take our work with people on breathing and managing breathlessness seriously.The group was launched in the Tweed Valley in January last year and already has a core of  people who attend regularly.They are also open for new singers. Member Ian said: ldquoThe singing exercises I perform during my fortnightly session at the Cheyne Gang have not only eased my breathing dficulties, I have also found them so easy to do at home.ldquoThe group of folk attending the sessions make you feel so welcome as does the music teacher.ldquoCongratulations to everyone involved on the first anniversary of our Cheyne Gang.ldquoWhy not come along and join us and feel the dference it makes to your breathing The next session is on Thursday, February , then Wednesday, March , from -pm in the Union Club, Peebles Road, Innerleithen.If you think the Cheyne Gang is something that might help you oryou work for NHS and would like to find out more about what they do, pop along to one of the sessions or contact Anne Ritchie at anne@thecheynegang.

title: andrew-and-jim-set-to-revive-forgotten-gems
story: POPULAR Scottish classics are to be served up at the Hawick Music Club later this month.The Agapanthus Duo will take to the stage at the Heart of Hawick on Sunday, February .Pianist Andrew Sherwood and violinist Jim Letham bring with them vast experience and a repertoire of great music.The duo champion many neglected Scottish composers.Jim, who was one-time president of Hawick Music Club, is a composer, pianist, educator and conductor of several choirs including the Abbey Consort.And has done a great deal to support and promote all forms of music in the Borders.Andrew grew up in Africa where he first picked up the violin as a teenager.A scholarship to the Royal College of Music led to a break with the Royal Opera House before freelancing in British orchestras including the Scottish Camber Orchestra and leading the Mercury Ensemble for Ballet Rambert.Performing has always gone hand in hand with teaching and he has been professor of violin at Trinity Labon Conservatoire for many years.His students visit the Borders every year and perform in Hawick.The Agapanthus Duo concert in Hawick starts at .pm on Sunday, February .Ticketsfor non-members are priced at pound for adults and free for accompanied under s.They are available from the Heart of Hawick box office on  .

title: colleges-salute-to-armed-forces
story: BORDERS College has nailed its colours to the mast by signing the Armed Forces Covenant.Signing the covenant demonstrates that the college recognises the value serving personnel, reservists, veterans and military families bring to the college.The college said that, by becoming a forces-friendly employer, it can benefit from the wide range of skills and experiences that reservists and veterans can bring to the organisation.Principal Angela Cox, Access to Unorm Services students and lecturer Damien Asquith , together with head of HR Debbie Kerr and head of student services Clare Nairn, all teamed up to sign the agreement.The college aims to uphold the principles of the Armed Forces Covenant including: promoting its armed forces-friendly status seeking to support the employment of veterans striving to support the employment and training of service spouses and partners flexibility in granting leave for service spouses and partners supporting employees who choose to be members of the reserve forces offering support to local cadet units and participating in Armed Forces Day.

title: cast-of-les-miserables-bring-barricades-to-hawick
story: STARS of the musical, Les Miseacuterables are coming to the Borders.Recreating West End and Broadway musical hit songs with amazing authenticity, the cast of past principal performers from Les Miseacuterables presents a blockbusting two-hour show.With a tour which has covered the UK, Spain, Malta, Denmark, Singapore, Hong Kong, New Zealand and Australia, Beyond the Barricade is in its th successive year.Now, Hawick Town Hall is set to be the next host of this, the UKrsquos longest-running musical theatre concert tour, which delivers the best of Broadway and the West End, with a stunning finale from Les Miseacuterables.The brand-new show for  will include many of the best numbers that have made Beyond the Barricade popular.The th Anniversary concerts feature David FawcettAndy ReissKatie Leemingand Poppy Tierney , together with a live band, capturing the feel of the original orchestrations of the chosen musicals.So, what can the audience at Hawick Town Hall expect ShowDirector, Andy Reiss said: ldquoWe take our audience on a journey through some of the greatest stage musicals including Miss Saigon, Phantom of the Opera, Blood Brothers, The Lion King, Hamilton and, of course, Les Miseacuterables.A former Les Miseacuterables performer himself, Reiss added: ldquoI wanted to make sure the songs were true to the original versions so that the audience could invest in sitting and listening to a concert version but be completely immersed in the storytelling of each particular song.ldquoLive Borders is proud to be hosting the epic Beyond the Barricade as part of their th anniversary tour."Beyond the Barricade takes to the Hawick Town Hall stage on Friday, February  at .p.Hamish Moir, events and programming officer at Live Borders, added: "Hawick Town Hall is a fantastic venue, and we really canrsquot wait to see these high-quality West End performers come to the local hall for what will be a night of incredible music for all the family."Ticketsare pound and available from www.liveborders.org.uk or by calling Border Events on  .

title: full-night-time-closures-of-galafoot-bridge-begin-this-week
story: DRIVERS are being warned that Galafoot Bridge is to be completely closed during night-times for the next fortnight.From Thursday, February , the A bridge between Galashiels and Melrose will shut to all traffic from pm to am.The current single-lane operation will continue during day-time hours.A spokesman for roads contractors Amey told us: "These night closures are to allow for the hydro-demolition of concrete on the structure."Sound reduction measures will be in place to minimise noise from the site, but due to the nature of the work, some noise disruption is still likely."We apologise in advance for any inconvenience this may cause."Unfortunately, this work cannot be carried out under day working as it requires the use of the full carriageway, to ensure the safety of road workers and the travelling public."The official westbound ersion will be via the A, A and A although Lowood Bridge will remain open.And eastbound traffic, as is the case during the day, will continue to be erted along the B by Abbotsford.

title: st-ronans-honour-the-bard
story: THE pupils of St. Ronanrsquos School in Innerleithen once again honoured the Bard by holding their th Annual Burns Lunch last week.As well as celebrating the birth of Robert Burns, the event commemorated the poets visit to Innerleithen in  when he took tea at Pirn House, where the school now stands.The schoolrsquos lunch was arranged by the Primary  pupils with guests from the community as well as the Primary  pupils and senior pupils from partner school, Walkerburn.In the chair was Sarah Whiteford who kept the proceedings moving along nicely.Piper Jim Hamilton, of Innerleithen Pipe Band, piped in the haggis, and Frances Reilly gave a stirring Address to the Haggis, albeit being a pre-recorded version on the big screen, as Frances was part of the Netball Team battling it out in the Borders School Final.The girls finished runners-up and ed in time for the speeches.Oliver Kennedy said the Selkirk Grace before a team of Primary  waiters and waitresses served up a delicious meal of haggis, neeps and tatties prepared by the St Ronanrsquos kitchen staff.Following the meal, a number of pupils delivered well-researched and humorous speeches.Freya Wilson proposed The Immortal Memory, which was accompanied by an imaginative slideshow.Freya reminded everyone of the Bardrsquos humble beginnings, his visit to Innerleithen and his colourful lestyle.The Toast to the Lassies was proposed by Marcus Adam who recounted Burnsrsquo love of the lassies, while taking the chance to gently poke fun at the girls, ultimately acknowledging that he couldnrsquot live without them.Eve Rathie replied on behalf of the lasses and managed to get a bit of her own back.Other toasts and replies were given by Eilish Henderson , Kylib Crawfordand Josh Landers .The Primary  and  pupils from Walkerburn - Ruby Patterson, Kaden Hunter, Melissa Lucas, Thomas Wilson and Kayleigh Zokas - delivered the reply on behalf of the Guests.St Ronans headteacher Keith Belleville told us: "Each young person taking part was very accomplished in the delivery of their role."The lunch was packed full of entertainment."The choir sang two songs with the children from Primary one getting in on the act with a Scottish version of the Hokey Cokey: The Shooglie Wooglie and a video link to the Nursery saw the children there present a Scottish medley.Throughout the afternoon the winners of the whole school Scots poetry recitation competition had entertained with their verses, which ranged from the works of J.K. Annand to Burns himself and showed off the considerable talent from across the school.The chief guest for the day was Alan Patterson, chairman of St. Ronanrsquos Border Games, who was joined by his we Dawn.Mr Patterson gave an inspiring address before presenting the awards to the winners of the poetry competition.The Burns Lunch closed with the singing of ldquoAuld Lang Syne.

title: more-jobs-and-space-as-specsavers-expand-in-galashiels
story: A LOCAL opticians has began work on a pound, expansion in Galashiels.Work on the major refit at Specsavers Galashiels started this week to provide new facilities, more space and additional services to customers, as well as creating a number of new jobs.The store expansion will see an extra test room added ndash fully kitted out with the latest clinical equipment for eye examination, new call centre capability and a fresh new look.Stuart Forrester, store director of Specsavers Galashiels, said: "Wersquore a big part of the community here in Galashiels and itrsquos so important that our store reflects the fantastic service we offer customers across both optical and audiology."The team is committed to providing our customers with the best possible service and we hope that the investment in our new store will improve their experience and encourage more people to visit us regularly."As well as making up to  more appointments available per week, the revamp will see customers being offered an extended range of Specsaversrsquo own and designer frames to choose from.The store will also continue to offer Digital Precision Eyecare, a cutting-edge way of selecting and fitting customersrsquo glasses, using imaging software on tablet devices.Disruption to customers will be kept to a minimum during the refurbishment.The store will close at pm on Saturday, February and will re-open at am on Monday, February .The grand unveiling of the completed new store is scheduled for March .

title: dementia-increases-in-the-borders-lead-to-redesign-of-services
story: NHS Borders chiefs have recorded regular increases in the number of patients being diagnosed with dementia.But they were among the worst in the country for providing post-diagnostic support services.The most recent figures available show that  Borders were diagnosed with some form of dementia during  .But only were given much-needed support - well down on the Scottish average of  percent.Improvements are on the horizon, though, as changes in the way post-diagnosis services are delivered are being implemented.A spokeswoman for NHS Borders told us: "The Mental Health Older Adults Service is currently working on a redesign of how post diagnostic support is delivered."It is our aim to deliver post diagnostic support that is tailored to the inidual needs of our patients."We have commenced work with a range of stakeholders, testing how we continue to best meet the needs of people with dementia and their families and carers in the Scottish Borders."Figures released by Information Services Division show that there were  new cases of dementia in the Borders during  .And the following year there were .The NHS Borders spokeswoman explained that recent changes make data comparisons for post-diagnostic services dficult.She added: "We have introduced a new IT system which has changed the way that we record and report data and makes reliable comparisons to past performance more dficult."We continue to work with colleagues at Information Services Division to more accurately capture and report on the work that we are doing.

title: borders-book-festivals-new-chapter-a-partnership-made-in-print
story: FROM humble beginnings the Borders Book Festival has grown into one of the top literary events in the country.And the -year-old celebration of everything in print is about to open a brand new chapter by teaming up with the regions favourite weekly newspapers.The Borderand Peeblesshire News have become official media partners of the Borders Book Festival.Not only will we bring you all the latest news of who will be turning the pages at Harmony Gardens this June, but we will have exclusive interviews with all of the authors, politicians, sports stars and entertainers.Jo Robinson, content editor of the Borderand Peeblesshire News, explained: "We are thrilled to be working so closely with the Borders Book Festival."Every year the organisers bring the biggest names in literature, sport, politics and entertainment to the beautul Harmony Gardens in Melrose - and we will have access to interview all of them for our readers to enjoy."We hope to have lots of live streaming from the festival and all of the news in the build up."The very first Borders Book Festival in  was held in the Wynd Theatre in front of an audience of around .Last year, despite storms causing several events to be cancelled, almost , visitors enjoyed the likes of Ian Rankin, Richard Dawkins, Stacey Dooley, Neil Oliver and The Hairy Bikers.This years line-up is currently being finalised but it already promises to be another star-studded, yet eclectic, line-up that will have some appeal for almost everyone.Borders Book Festival Director Alistair Moffat is delighted with the new media partnership.He said: "Local roots are strong roots."When we started this festival  years ago, we knew that the most important people to attract were our neighbours."If they liked it, then so would others who lived further afield."Over that long period, the festival has grown to become the one moment in the year when the world comes to the Borders. Instead of catching a train to see big names in Edinburgh or London, they come to us in June in Melrose."But we will never forget our local roots and that is why a partnership with the Borderand the Peeblesshire News is vital."We are told that we have more Facebook friends in Dubai than in one of the Border towns and we are determined that with the help of the Borderand the Peeblesshire News, we will change that."This years Festival runs from Thursday, June  through to Sunday, June .As well as talks and signings by many of the biggest names in books, television, sport and politics there will also be the hugely-popular childrens book festival, delightful musical performances, fine dining in the orchard and so much more over the four days.Dont miss the Borderand Peeblesshire News for the full programme of events.Festival co-ordinator Paula Ogilvie believes the Festival has something for everyone. She explained: "The festival is proud of its place in Borders le, working alongside many partner organisations and writersrsquo groups to combine our main festival programme with community events and a  for local authors, artists and youth groups to showcase their work.,params: .push"Young people are at the heart of the celebrations, with thousands of families, nursery and schoolchildren joining us each year at our bustling Family Book Festival and educational events, and many talented local young people form the backbone of our team by helping to shape our programme, and by performing, presenting and welcoming our visitors to Harmony Garden and Orchard in Melrose over a packed weekend in June."We are thrilled to forge this exciting new partnership with our friends at the Borderand Peeblesshire News and canrsquot wait to start sharing all our latest festival news."Further details of the Border Book Festival are available at http:www.bordersbookfestival.org and https:www.facebook bordersbookfestival

title: success-continues-as-selkirk-farmers-market-sells-out
story: STALLS at Selkirk Farmers Market have sold out for the remainder of .The monthly town centre markets started last summer.And a waiting list was quickly needed as traders from near and far scrambled for the  stalls.Selkirkshire councillor Caroline Penman said: "The February market was slightly quieter than normal due to clashing with the rugby international and other events, but it was still fairly busy."The stalls are now fully booked right up to the end of the year."Local organisations also receive a boost from the monthly Market with groups receiving pound for assembling and taking down the stalls.Councillor Penman added: "The volunteer groups are also now full for the rest of ."

title: council-has-long-held-ambition-to-improve-lowood-bridge
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council has lsquolong-held ambitionsrsquo to transform Lowood Bridge, it has been claimed.At last Wednesdayrsquos meeting of Galashiels Community Council, members were told local authority bosses want to ease congestion around the -year-old structure.But it wonrsquot happen soon.Martin Joyce, SBCrsquos director of assets and infrastructure told the meeting: ldquoWhen proposing the new Tweedbank development, we had people come out and look at the bridge to ensure it is suitable to cope.ldquoThe conclusion was that the level of traffic the new development will bring, will be insufficient to replace Lowood Bridge. However, there is a long-held ambition by in the roads department to increase capacity.ldquoThis could mean creating two lanes, or a separate smaller bridge. But this is not something the council has made allowances for in its capital budget.The Grade-B listed crossing was closed for  weeks last year while repairs were carried out as part of a pound, strengthening programme.

title: ae-waits-at-worst-level-for-15-years
story: AE waiting times in England have reached their worst level since records began, data shows.Figures from NHS England show that, during January, just .% of patients were treated or admitted in four hours, against a % target.This meansnearly , patients waited longer than they should, and comes despite lower levels of flu and norovirus than last year.The data shows that , people in January endured very long waits ndash often called trolley waits ndash to be admitted to hospital.After a decision had been taken to admit them, this group waited four hours or more before a ward bed was found for them.The last time the % target ndash which was introduced in  ndash was hit was in July .Nuffield Trust chief economist Professor John Appleby said:ldquoTodayrsquos figures remind us that the NHS is fighting a losing battle in trying to meet its commitments to provide timely healthcare in the face of the pressure it is under.ldquoThere is a risk that we lose sight of these problems as Brexit distracts us, or become numbed as we forget the last time targets were met.ldquoBut this situation has a serious impact on hundreds of thousands of patients, and will be demoralising for many staff.ldquoThe proportion of patients spending more than four hours in AE has risen to .% in January ndash the highest ever in this set of data.ldquoIt looks like the gap between the servicersquos capacity and the care we need from it is widening.He said only two AE departments in England met the four-hour target and attendances have risen by an ldquoastonishing , compared with January last year, at a time in the year when they would usually fall.ldquoLast year, there was widespread concern as we saw trolley waits balloon, yet todayrsquos figures show an even higher level, he said.Royal College of Emergency Medicinepresident, Dr Taj Hassan, said: ldquoSadly the situation afflicting our emergency departments has become seemingly normalised with a lsquochronic crisis modersquothat does not allow staff to deliver the quality of care they would wish and patients should rightly expect.ldquoThe evidence on resultant crowding in departments is clear ndash it adds to the risk of harm to patients leading to excess deaths and disability.ldquoThese figures make clear the true scale of this crisis facing our systems.Shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth said:ldquoAE waiting times are now at their worst level since records began, which is a damning indictment of years of austerity and wider cuts imposed upon health and care services under the Tories.ldquoMinisterial incompetence has left our NHS with chronic shortages of NHS staff with no clear idea of how to sort this out.Patricia Marquis, director of the Royal College of Nursingin England, said of trolley waits:ldquoNo nurse ever wants to leave patients on trolleys in corridors or waiting for hours in an armchair when therersquos no bed.But she added: ldquoItrsquos not just about beds, we also need the nurses to safely staff them.A spokesman for the NHS said thousands more people have been successfully treated in AE within four hours than last year.This is because the total number of attendances has gone up story: Theresa May is facing another testing day in the Commons with the threat of members of her party rebelling against a key Commons vote on her EU withdrawal stance.Eurosceptic Conservatives could vote against or abstain on the Governmentrsquos motion, which Tory critics insist effectively means the Prime Minister is abandoning a no-deal exit option.Ahead of the main vote, three amendments have been selected which could also hamper the Governmentrsquos plans, although these votes are not legally binding.The Speaker has provisionally selected the following amendments to todays #BrexitNextStepsmotion:ndash @jeremycorbynndash @IanBlackfordMPndash @Anna_SoubryRead all amendments here: https:t.co GDlfYJLDwLpic QqIUOursKmdash UK House of CommonsFebruary , .pmEuropean Research Group chairman Jacob Rees-Mogg said it was ldquohighly unlikely that eurosceptic Tories would vote against the Government in Thursday eveningrsquos votes.Mr Rees-Mogg told ITV News: ldquoTodayrsquos business is not fundamentally important. deal or allow Parliament to decide what happens next.ldquoI would hope that anyone who genuinely opposes no deal would see that an extension by that date, th March, is unavoidable..pmSir Keir Starmer came under pressure from his own party colleagues to confirm holding another referendum on the Brexit deal would now be the next step for Labour.Labour MP Ben Bradshawurged him to act sooner rather ldquoconfidential.He added: ldquoThere must come a point where the options are claried and reduced, then voted upon, and I agree with that proposition and it needs to be done before the end of That is not holding your nerve, that is plain reckless and we have to say no.Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer addresses MPs .pmSir Keir drew on his past dealings with the PM as he said he did not think Mrs May would take the UK out of the EU without a deal because of her ldquodeep sense of duty.The former Director of Public Prosecutions said he had worked with Mrs May when she was Home Secretary, saying she had a ldquodeep sense of duty, adding: ldquoAnd deep down I do not think that this Prime Minister will take us out of the EU on the th of March, and thatrsquos the basis that we should be having this conversation.Sir Keir also suggested the likelihood of getting an improved deal which fixes the issues some MPs have with the backstop before we are due to exit the EU are ldquoslim.The shadow Brexit secretary said: ldquoThe simple and painful truth is thisthere had been a viable alternative to the backstop there would never have been a backstop..pmShadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer urged MPs not to be ldquofooled the Prime Minister was continuing to negotiate in earnest.He said: ldquoIt is obvious what the Prime Minister is up to ndash she is pretending to make progress while running down the clock.ldquoA non-update every other week to buy another two weeks of process, inching ever closer to the th March deadline in  days. title: letter kintyre needs a modern connectivity system
story: The Scottish Government is seeking views on the proposed future Glasgow to Campbeltown air service prior to it being retendered.I have discussed this specic issue with friends and we have concerns about the current unreliable ferry, air services and road link.We believe we should receive at the very least the same air service as provided to the island of Islay.We have the following thoughts on improvements to encourage new businesses to locate here and to promote tourism.We would like a larger Saab  or equivalent aircraft that can land in more adverse weather conditions # we understand the economies of scale and suggest a service that can fly to Campbeltown and then on to Islay, back to Campbeltown and ing to Glasgow, or vice versa.We would like the reinstatement of the radar system to assist landings in adverse weather conditions.As there is a separate service between Islay and Edinburgh we suggest that Campbeltown should be included as we also have key tourist attractions such as distilleries and three fantastic -hole golf courses and high-standard accommodation.We would like to see the service continue with a timetable with low ticket prices to allow the full day in Glasgow for NHS appointments, business and shopping trips and the reinstatement of seven days a week flights to enhance business and tourism.In addition, we want national advertising campaigns inclusive of timetables to promote the area for increased passenger numbers, including weekend breaks.These aspirations are very much in keeping with the council’s Community Plan Single Outcome Agreement   in particular relating to National Policy Priorities i.e. economic recovery, growth and employment.We are also very much aware of organisations which have worked hard to promote the long-term outcomes in the Community Plan.The communities of Kintyre need a modern connectivity system, fit for purpose,this area is to have any credibility in the big wide world.Decent flight connections to the major hubs of Glasgow and Edinburgh would be a start.I have confirmed the Scottish Government is collecting views andyou would like to help improve our air service and have additional comments or suggestions, I urge you to email them to: Michael.Bratcher@transport. gov.scotAndrew Hemmings,

title: thought for the week february 1 2019
story: February  marks the midpoint of winter, half way between the shortest day and the spring equinox.For Christians it has a particularly special meaning as it was  days after the birth of Jesus and the day when, according to Jewish custom, his grateful parents took him to the temple to give thanks to God.We believe that Jesus is the light of the world who will guide us through our own dark times.Many customs have grown around Candlemas and one of the most interesting came from Scotland.In the olden days, Candlemas was the day when children brought candles to school so that the classrooms would have light on dull days.As time went on, gas lighting took over from candlelight and the children brought money to school with which the teacher was supposed to buy sweets for the children.The child who brought in the most money was declared Candlemas King or Queen and they ruled for six weeks.They had the power to make one whole afternoon a week a playtime and to excuse anyone they wished from any form of punishment.I don#t think this will catch on in Argyll!I think it is a lovely custom to take a child to church or temple for a blessing and to give thanks to God for their birth.I have the privilege of being chaplain to two primary schools and while I cannot take the children physically to church or temple, I take each one of them to God every day in my prayers to give thanks for them and ask God#s blessing upon them.

Then when Dr Abernethy left surgery, he continued to call on the patient, right up until .pm at night.It was at this time that the doctor decided to drive Mr Singal to Campbeltown Hospital.And finally, at am, Dr Abernethy insisted that his patient be taken by air ambulance to Glasgow.It was here that surgeons performed a tracheotomy on Mr Singal, an incision made when the air passage has been blocked # his throat had #swelled like a balloon#.The surgeons told Mr Singal thatit hadn#t been for the actions of the local doctor, he would have been dead.#This man saved my le, it#s as simple as that,# Jerry said this week. #His dedication to this village is out of this world.#FIFTY YEARS AGOThe oldest # and the championAlthough Kintyre Agricultural Society#s annual ploughing match was postponed on Saturday because of the state of the ground, the Islay Ploughing Society went ahead with its competition.The T Jarret Trophy for the best ploughed lot on the field was won by Alex Campbell, Woodend Cottages, Ballygrant, who was the oldest competitor.The competition was held on Islay House Home Farm, by courtesy of Lord Margadale of Islay.The judge was Mr Ewan McPherson of Dalrannoch, Barcaldine, and the prizes were presented by Mrs Donald McGillivray.They were thanked by the secretary, Mr Donald McIntyre, Ballygrant, as were the ladies who did the catering , the donors of the prizes, and all who had helped to make the match a success.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOA firm answerSober men will heartily approve the firm reply which the government promptly dispatched to the threatening ultimatum which the strikers on the Clyde transmitted through the Lord Provost of Glasgow.The Clyde is the most notorious centre of operations of the extreme revolutionary section of organised Labour.The demands that are now made are both in the method of making them and in their character of violation not only of the established methods of industrial bargaining, but of the first principles of civil order.The strike is not authorised by the responsible executive of the union concerned.And the ultimatum of the strikers to the government was not an appeal for arbitration in the accepted sense but a demand that the government should forthwith champion the case of the strikers and coerce the employers into unconditional surrender.This demand was accompanied by threats suggestive of the highwayman#s formula: #Your money or your le.#Now it is patent that the business of government, the commerce of the country, and the stability of the social fabric cannot be conducted and sustainedthere is any shilly shallying with such reckless minorities as those responsible for such an ultimatum as this.

title: down memory lane february 8 2019
story: That year NASA was formed as the two Cold War superpowers, America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics , vied for off world power and raced to put a man in space.Angus MacVicar, a Courier editor in the s, was a novelist determined that Scotland would have a starring role.Last week, while on holiday, a Courier reporter spotted MacVicar#s  work in the eclectic collection of a Great Malvern, Worcestershire second-hand bookshop.The cover features a dish for communicating with a geostationery satellite, such as the first Telstar, launched in , and a rocket launching pad.The two are connected by a road with an uncanny resemblance to the track leading to the Mull lighthouse.Angus, who eventually bought a property in Southend and lived to , before passing away in , belonged to a North Uist family whose history can be traced back  years.The flyleaf to the book states he became a #hard working newspaperman#   at the Courier in , after graduating from Glasgow University and, when the editor Alec MacLeod, had a serious ilness, in  stepped up to the hot seat.Not content with writing all day, Angus, in the words of another former Courier reporter, Freddy Gillies: #burned the midnight oil,# to write the first of  novels # The Purple Rock, published in  by Stanley Paul.He left to become a full-time author and broadcaster although the Second World War intervened.Angus took part in three assault landings # Madagascar, Sicily and Italy and was mentioned in dispatches for his part in the break-out at Anzio.Satellite , costing three shillings and six pence, was published  years before Paul McCartney came to Kintyre and tells the tale of radio and television singing star, Tony Thomson, aged  and his younger brother Jake.They are shipwrecked on a remote Hebridean island, find a government research station and are detained by the inhabitants.Eventually some of the mystery is unravelled  when they learn Britain is about to launch its seventh satellite, built to circle the moon andwith the first photographs of its dark side.Angus#s first volume of autobiography, Salt In My Porridge, subtitled Confession#s of a Minister#s son, was published in  and reprinted five times.It was first issued in paperback in  and currently changes hands for between . pence and £..Graeme Baird at the Old Bookshelf in Cross Street said that Angus# books are in great demand.The front cover of Satellite  features a tarred road which looks remarkably similar to the Mull lighthouse track. story: Arran McAllister, of Kintyre trad band Rhuvaal which rocked a Burns Night gig at Google#s UK headquarters, played guitar and sang on the Victoria Hall stage with his uncle and accordionist Alex McAllister.They joined other entertainers, Kintyre Schools Pipe Band, singers Hannah Black, Robert McCallum, and Cha and Annmarie McLean, as well as junior dancers from James McCorkindale#s School of Dancing, at the annual senior citizens# concert last Saturday.Much of the entertainment was upbeat, with people unable to stop their hands clapping and their toes tapping, but at times it was ethereal # you could hear a pin drop during Cha and Annmarie#s Gaelic duets.More than  people attended the event which is organised and run by Campbeltown Community Council , and more than half won a prize in the free raffle, with shops, hotels and pubs making donations.The afternoon#s MC, Kay Johnston, was thanked for keeping things running smoothly by CCC chairman Alan Baker, who presented her with a bunch of flowers.Former CCC member Cathy Duncan, who has helped organise the event for the last five or six years, was finally able to sit back, relax and enjoy the afternoon, as current members dished out tea, coffee and light bites supplied by Argyll Bakeries.Volunteers from Campbeltown Sea Cadets also helped to serve at the event.Mr Baker thanked everyone who had helped for making the afternoon #a great success#.Rhuvaal#s Arran McAllister and his uncle Alex McAllister on stage. _cseniorsCathy Duncan, third left, enjoyed the concert with friends. _cseniorsGillian MacIntyre joined her granny, Violet Dixon, who moved to Campbeltown from Rothesay last year, at the event. _cseniorsSome of the Campbeltown Community Council members who organised and ran the event. _cseniorsAnnmarie and Cha McLean sang a range of Gaelic songs. _cseniorsSea cadets Elyce Walker, James Ives, Joseph Davies, APO Greg Walker, Beth MacPherson and Isaac Morbey helped. _cseniorsLadies enjoying the concert. _cseniorsAlan Baker thanked everyone who contributed after presenting Kay Johnston with a bunch of flowers. _cseniorsMore than  people attended the concert. _cseniors

title: the sinopia quartet a review by david mcewan
story: The truthfulness of this was proved at the recent Kintyre Music Club concert last Friday.The Sinopia Quartet # two violins, viola and cello # delighted its audience with the works of just three composers – Bartók, Borodin and Dvořák.Bartók was a Hungarian who was a keen collector of folk melodies. The astringent harmonies, for which he was famous, underpinned six short Romanian folk dances with great effect.This piece was followed by Borodin’s famous nd Quartet.The melody forming part of the slow movement was used in the famous  musical Kismet.Borodin, a Russian, was a doctor and chemist by profession and composed music in his spare time. The second quartet revealed his total mastery of composition.After the interval the audience was treated to Dvořák’s #American# quartet. This was a piece bursting with fine tunes and boundless energy.With the players providing helpful information about the pieces, this concert was felt to be one of the best of the season.It proved the point that careful programme-planning incorporating plenty of good tunes usually sends everyone away happy.The players hands and arms are a blur as they play Bartók#s fast dance Maruntelul. _cSinopia_Kintyre_Music_ClubLorne and Lowland Old Church Hall was quite warm and Sinopia players had to tune-up regularly. _cSinopia_Tune_up

title: kilkivan chapel and cemetery preservation
story: At a meeting in Machrihanish Village Hall on Monday, it was agreed to form a group to investigate how the buildings at Kilkivan could be preserved.Angus Nimmo spoke of his personal connections with Kilkivan.He described how at the end of the Sunday School year, the children and their parents from Drumlemble Mission Hall would walk to Kilkivan.They would meet with the children and parents from Machrihanish for a short service and picnic.Mike Peacock presented a slideshow illustrating the historical grave slabs.He described the state of the cemetery from his arrival at Trodigal until the present day and how it had deteriorated.Councillor John Armour stated that Kilkivan was a closed cemetery.Therefore there would only be minimum maintenance by Argyll and Bute Council, probably a once-a-year grass cut.After some discussion about the grave slabs at Skipness and Saddell and the cemeteries at Killean and Kilchenzie, it was agreed to hold a further meetingIt will be in Machrihanish Village Hall on Monday March  at .pm and representatives of Argyll and Bute Council and Historic Environment Scotland will be invited.Everyone with an interest in preserving this important historical site is welcome to come to this meeting.Kilkivan cemetery. _ckilkivancemetery
