title: strikes-imminent-at-queen-margaret-university
story: The industrial action is scheduled for next Thursday , next Mondayand next Wednesday .The strikes follow a ballot of University and College UnionScotland members in which  per cent of those who voted supported industrial action on a turnout of  per cent.Those set to strike work in academic and academic-related positions, including the library and student support.The union says the row centres on cuts that would put more than  jobs at risk.It argues that alternatives to the current plans ndash including resource sharing, management savings and extending the period of restructuring ndash have not been sufficiently explored. The local branch is considering its next steps.The university employs  staff.A spokesperson from Queen Margaret University said: ldquoWe are still actively in discussions with both unions, with meetings scheduled for next week, and are hopeful that we can make sufficient progress at these talks to avoid industrial action.ldquoAs always, we will make every effort to minimise the impact of any strike action on our studentssuch action takes place.Mary Senior, UCU Scotland official, previously said that strike action was always a ldquolast resort, adding: ldquoUCU members at Queen Margaret University have made it absolutely clear that they have no confidence in the universityrsquos plans.ldquoThe ballot result is a clear mandate for industrial action and to oppose plans for compulsory redundancies.ldquoAxing  per cent of the workforce would have a huge impact on the student experience and on the universityrsquos reputation.The QMU spokesperson earlier said: ldquoThe university has not declared compulsory redundancies, committing itself to seeking to achieve the required reductions in staff costs voluntarily, and is making good progress on achieving this.ldquoAlong with the rest of the higher education sector, QMU faces financial challenges, with grant funding falling in real terms over recent years and rising costs such as pension and National Insurance contributions.ldquoDespite a positive growth trajectory overall at QMU, with costs increasing faster than our income, we have had to take action to reset the balance and thus ensure we can continue to lead in providing relevant teaching and research.

title: pressure-on-scottish-ministers-to-release-cockenzie-site-report
story: The Scottish Government called in a planning application to build a substation on the former Cockenzie Power Station site last March after the land was bought by East Lothian Council.Now, Scottish Conservatives are demanding the findings of the investigation be made public after they were sent to Ministers in private.South of Scotland MSP Michelle Ballantyne said the decision, which came after months of public hearings and representation, ldquobeggars belief, while ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said people were left wondering what the Scottish Government was doing ldquobehind closed doors.East Lothian Labour MSP Iain Gray has already tabled a motion at the Scottish Parliament demanding a public update on the decision as offshore windfarm company Inch Cape, which put in the planning application to build the substation, begins eight weeks of ldquoinvestigative work there.And East Lothian Council has said it is also considering writing to the Scottish Government, adding: ldquoThe council believes it is important for there to be transparency in the decision-making process.The decision on the application by Inch Cape, which is owned by Chinese state-owned company Red Rock, was taken away from council planners as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was on an official visit to China last March.Inch Capersquos plans to bring energy from an offshore windfarm onto land at Cockenzie have been criticised by the council and communities for potentially sterilising a large area of land which has the potential to bring over , jobs to the county.The Scottish Government reporter scrutinised hundreds of documents from all sides and oversaw a public hearing in Cockenzie late last year.Her findings have been passed to Scottish Minister but are not being made public at this stage.The Scottish Government said: ldquoAn independent planning reporter was appointed to consider this case, produce a report and make recommendations in order for the final decision to be taken by Scottish Ministers.ldquoThe reporter has submitted her report and recommendations on the proposal and a decision will be made in due course.A council spokesperson said: ldquoWe understand that the reporterrsquos findings are now with Scottish Ministers, who will now determine the Inch Cape planning application, and that the contents of the report will be made public when that decision is announced.ldquoThe council believes it is important for there to be transparency in the decision-making process. We are considering possible correspondence with the Scottish Government on this matter. The leader of the council has also indicated that he will be writing to express similar concern to the minister.Mr Gray said the decision on the future of the site should never have been taken away from the council in the first place. He said: ldquoIt is of such great importance to the communities affected and the whole of East Lothian that it should have been determined by East Lothian Council and local people.ldquoThe community needs to know what is happening and what the Scottish Governmentrsquos decision will be, which is why I have tabled a question in Parliament asking Ministers to provide an urgent update.Conservative councillor Mr Bruce said: ldquoThe Scottish Government denied the local authorityrsquos right to make a decision on this application in the first place, making the whole process unfair and open to proper local scrutiny.ldquoThe fact that the report still hasnrsquot been released continues to shroud this whole saga in mystery and will leave many local people wondering what the Scottish Government is doing behind closed doors.And MsBallantyne added:ldquoItrsquos incumbent on the Scottish Government to be open and transparent over their decision-making process.ldquoDuring the formation of the report, the public engaged heavily by taking part in public hearings and contributing towards the report. Local stakeholders deserve to know the outcome of the report and, quite frankly, it beggars belief that the Scottish Government have chosen to keep this secret.

title: events-held-in-memory-of-much-missed-footballer-craig-fairgrieve
story: Craig Fairgrieve was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemiain  and passed away in July last year.Now, two fundraising events are taking place to raise funds for Ward  at Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.The first fundraiser takes place at Dalkeith Miners Club, with a second event at Cockenzie and Port Seton Royal British Legion just over a fortnight later.Craigrsquos sister Lynsay is among those planning the event in Dalkeith on February .She said: ldquoCraig was a friend to everybody.ldquoHe was very laid back ndashhe was more laid back he would be horizontal.ldquoIf somebody tooted at him in the street he would wave and he liked a bit of banter.ldquoHe was notorious for lines out of films and he was a cheeky chappy and a guy with a smile on his face.Craig, of Prestonpans, played football for Tranent Juniors under-s after growing up in Macmerry and going to Ross High School in Tranent.He began to feel unwell towards the end of .His we Amy said: ldquoIt all started with tiredness. Craig was going to work and coming home absolutely exhausted.ldquoWe thought this was not normal and he got sent for blood tests.ldquoThat was when we discovered it was leukaemia and he started treatment at the Western General Hospital.Craig, who was just  when he passed away, underwent chemotherapy and a stem cell transplant as part of his treatment.Positively, he was told the condition was in remission and he was released from hospital, getting engaged in October .However, the leukaemia ed and Craig and Amy tied the knot in the Capitalrsquos hospital on July .Amy said: ldquoHis final wish was to get married.ldquoThe ward was really, really good and got it together. I was given a wedding dress from one of the nurses they were brilliant.A raffle and auction will be held at the first fundraiser, with prizes ranging from football tickets and golf vouchers to hair and beauty and bootcamp vouchers all up for grabs.Music will be supplied on the night by a DJ and Lynsay, , explained why the event was taking place outwith East Lothian. She said: ldquoA lot of the East Lothian venues were just too small.ldquoWe tried to keep it in East Lothian but we are looking for  tickets to be sold.ldquoThe tickets are out there and we are pretty much down to the last  or .Money raised on the night will go to the haematology wardat the hospital.Ahead of the event, more than pound, has already been raised. Meanwhile, the second fundraiser, on March , is a drag queen evening and disco.Amy said: ldquoThat is the sort of person Craig was ndash he was always up for a laugh and all about a good time.For ticketsto the fundraiser in Dalkeith, contact Kayleigh Szymanski or Dave Forsyth, and for tickets to the fundraiser in Cockenzie call Charles Brown on  .To make a donation, go to justgiving crowdfunding craig-fairgrieve

title: port-at-old-power-station-site-could-cost-same-as-new-school
story: A conference hosted by Prestonpans Community Council heard that building a cruise port could prove cost effective for East Lothian Council, which owns the land,it were then leased to port operators.Transport consultant Roy Pedersen, from Port of Copenhagen, told a gathering of councillors, officials and interested parties that a similar project in his homeland had been successfully introduced at a cost of pound million.And he said that the cruise ship terminal at Visby was built by its local authority and then leased to a private company for  years in a move which would repay most of the capital cost.Prestonpans Community Council, which is promoting the idea of a cruise ship port at the former Cockenzie Power Station site, said the Copenhagen example showed how it could work.Urging East Lothian Council to take the idea forward and investigate its potential, they said in a statement: ldquoSuch a capital cost does not seem so very dferent from the cost of building a school and would repay for itself over time under a lease arrangement with the public sector retaining ownership.The conference wasaddressed by community councillor Calum Miller, who told the invited audience: ldquoThere is a huge untapped potential for businesses across East Lothian, the creation of a hospitality college, re-stocking ships with local goods and produce, as well as the income that could be generated for the council from port fees.The meeting, in Prestonpans last Friday, had been criticised by some members of neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton community who oppose the port.It is understood at least one resident wrote to the local authorityrsquos chief executive expressing concern that officials would be attending the meeting and calling it ldquoa grave mistake to do so.A council spokesperson said: ldquoIt was entirely appropriate for council members and officers to take up invitations to attend. The seminar event consisted of presentations around cruise and port potential for the site.East Lothian Council produced its own masterplan for the site, which is described as a vision document, but plans are on hold as the outcome of a planning application to build a substation on the land is decided by Scottish Ministers.The council said a series of spring lsquoengagement eventsrsquo were planned for local communities to discuss the future of the site.

title: north-berwick-artists-exhibition-based-on-medication
story: NORTH Berwick artist Andrew Guest is displaying his medicinal artwork in his local pharmacy for a week to make a statement about peoplersquos relationship with tablets and medicine.A series of clay pots cast from the box of every piece of medication that Andrew took between  and , including everyday tablets such as paracetamol and ibuprofen, as well as the first types of tablets he took after being diagnosed with Parkinsonrsquos disease, are displayed in the window of Smithrsquos Pharmacy on High Street.The -year-old moved to North Berwick in  and, after a career as an exhibition officer putting on displays of other peoplersquos art, decided to make his own, completing courses in ceramics at Gateshead before studying pottery in Edinburgh.ldquoIrsquove always been interested in recycling and waste materials, especially pill packaging, he said.ldquoI just started making each box in clay, one for each pot, and it started there really. Itrsquos fascinating, and so much fun plasting and casting objects.ldquoI find a real beauty in the ordinary. I canrsquot paint some unique and beautul scene, but I can create something that people see everyday, and give them a chance to see it in a new light. It is also a picture of one personrsquos dependency on this method of treatment.Sheila Pearson, sales supervisor at Smithrsquos Pharmacy said: ldquoItrsquos generated some interest. People are stopping and looking and taking notice. It seems to be a positive reaction so far.The exhibition is on show at the pharmacy until Sunday.

title: tims-tales-the-senseless-feud
story: MOTORISTS speeding home from work from Edinburgh on the A may sometimes notice an old beehive-shaped doorsquocot on their left soon after they pass the junction for Wallyford and just before the first junction for Tranent.The doorsquocot is surrounded by a crumbling ancient wall. The doorsquocot is a clue that once a residence of some signicance stood here. It was called Dolphingstone Castle. Nothing now visibly remains of the castle, but around  years ago ruins were still to be seen.It was at one time an elegant mansion, but before that, on the same site, an older castle once stood ndash now all gone, and the structures of modernity are hemming in what is left of this ancient site. A wave of new housing laps at its walls to the west, the A traffic roars past on its south, and roads surround it on other quarters.One wondersthis small slice of East Lothian history will survive the developers. I hope it does. It is a small, historic fingerprint and gives a mysterious glimpse into our countyrsquos past, in an area now being carpeted with thousands of new houses.Earlier maps suggest that Dolphingstone Castle was surrounded by woodland. So perhaps the planting of a small wood or orchard within the old walls could create an island of both nature and history amidst the tide of urbanising development in this area.Up above on the ridge of Falside Hill to the south, the restored Farsquoside Castle looks down on the developments below . It sits like an eagle perched on a high ridge, observing the land below.How dferent the landscape it surveys would have been in  when, according to an old story, a small force of hand-picked warriors descended from the castle under the cover of darkness.It was just past midnight when they left, guided by a slither of moon. It was a raiding party, bent on revenge and heading for Preston Tower in what is now Prestonpans.Tradition tells us a feud had existed between the houses of Farsquoside and Preston for some years. The cause of the feud was the breaking down of walls between the two estates and the animals of each side grazing on the land of the other. Regular, and sometimes violent, clashes had taken place.But then Hamilton of Prestonrsquos livestock had been poisoned, or so it seemed. They had drunk from a burn which flowed from Farsquoside and it was assumed the water had been deliberately poisoned. Hamilton of Preston Tower, making no investigation, sent his men on a raid of violent retribution.Farsquoside Castle was attacked and blood was shed. This was the act which the select band of warriors who had set forth from Farsquoside were to avenge.In darkness, they filed down from the ridge on a path now known as Whinney Loan. This took them down to where the new houses are now being built on the southern edge of Wallyford.From here, great care was needed lest they be seen or heard. Dolphingstone Castle lay ahead and although their grievance was not with the occupants of Dolphingstone, early discovery could ruin the element of surprise.So the raiders veered north of Dolphingstone, by way of Prestoungrange, and at dawn, with the smell of the salt pans in their noses, they set about their vengeful work.Screams and running bairns alerted the occupants of Preston Tower. Armed men were ready, for this raid was expected, although not from this direction.The walls of Preston Tower held the attackers at bay but the people of the village suffered the worst of the slaughter. What senseless violence: neighbours separated only by the brae of a hill had been whipped up into a hateful frenzy against each other. Gradually the raiders melted away, back up the hill, with blooded swords.But hate builds on hate and the reckoning was not slow in coming. The very next day, Hamilton of Preston led a force westwards. It arrived by the walls of Dolphingstone Castle and then rounded past them to head up the hill towards Farsquoside, crossing where now the A speeds by.No attempt at surprise was required, this was to be an open fight. The Lord of Farsquoside had arranged his men along the top of the ridge, looking down on the approaching force of Hamiltonrsquos men. The order to charge was given and the men of Farsquoside poured down the slope.The leaders of both sides were in the thick of the fighting. It was the Lord of Farsquoside who fell, pulled from his horse and hacked to death by Hamiltonrsquos men.Seeing the death of their leader, the men of Farsquoside fled back to the castle. But the Lady of Farsquoside, in shock and rage at the death of her husband, rallied the men. She led them out of the castle in a furious charge as the sun began to set, forcing Hamiltonrsquos men to flee back to Preston.The battle, or skirmish as some would call it, was over, and the feud had reached its bloody climax. Soon after it was discovered an infectious disease had stricken the cattle, not poisoned water. Cattle on both sides had been equally affected. No one was to blame.How easy it had been to make enemies out of neighbours based on  assumptions. We are told Hamilton attempted to make amends. But the dead could not rise and the Lady of Farsquoside was said to be devastated at the loss of her husband. We can be sure others of lesser status suffered no less.This feud was over little remains to record it except tradition passed down, captured and retold by th-century writers such as P MrsquoNeill and Robert Seton, from whose works this account is garnished.Preston Tower still stands in Prestonpans, in a ruined but still defiant state. Farsquoside, much restored, is a visual delight still keeping watch atop the ridge. But only those feint hinds of Dolphingstone Castle remain, most of it lost to time and mystery just like the details of this story.But all the more reason to preserve and value them, I think.

title: betting-businesses-told-to-monitor-gambling-habits-of-people-on-benefits
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board has approved a new gambling policy which puts the responsibility for policing the risks of betting in the hands of new licensees.Among the issues that new applicants will have to prove they have addressed before being given a licence will be monitoring ldquogaming trends that may reflect benefit payments, ldquoidentying and reporting attempts to launder money on premises and ldquoprotecting vulnerable people and those with gambling dependencies.Approving the new draft policy, which will govern the boardrsquos licensing decisions for the next three years, board members raised concerns about a lack of legislation to stophigh streets in deprived communities becoming lined with betting shops.Councillor Lachlan Bruce, Preston Seton Gosford ward member, called for current laws which prevent local authorities from refusing a licence to betting businesses because of overprovision to be changed.He said that it was impossible to walk down some town centre streets without being confronted by gambling premises offering promotions and deals.Mr Bruce told the meeting: ldquoThere are high streets in East Lothian where [betting shops] seem to be every  yards.ldquoThere is an issue where it is impossible to avoid gambling premises.The board was told that the Gambling Act  precluded using overprovision as a reason to refuse a licence for a betting shop.The councilrsquos new policy will put the onus for local risk assessments on applicants who want to open licensed gambling premises ranging from bookies to casinos, bingo halls, tracks and travelling fairs.Board member Councillor Jane Henderson, North Berwick Coastal, spoke of the dangers of gambling addiction, saying: ldquoGambling is an extremely destructive situation and sometime it does not get the headlines other things do.ldquoBut it crosses all walks of le and we, as a board and as iniduals, have a moral duty to recognise it is as much an illness as anything  and anything we can do to help should be taken very seriously.Councillor Willie Innes, council leader and Preston Seton Gosford ward member, cautioned that only a minority of people who gambled were affected by addiction and for others it was simply an activity they enjoyed.He told board members: ldquoWhen I first joined the council, gambling was a backstreet activity with premises down back alleys and it took us a long time to persuade the industry to come onto the high street.Mr Innes said that the new policy, which set out additional risk assessment requirements for applicants, sent ldquoa clear message to both the industry and those concerned about it.

title: prominent-cockenzie-campaigner-larry-tomlins-remembered
story: Larry Tomlins, who was chairman of Cockenzie West Tenants and Residents Association, was involved in campaigns to reduce speeding and upgrade local park facilities in his community.The grandfather-of-two was an active supporter of the recent fight to implement speeding restrictions outside new housing at The Chimneys, Cockenzie, and helped oversee the trial and subsequent introduction of  miles per hourspeed limits in the Whin Park area of the village.Mr Tomlins, , grew up in Ayrshire and moved to Cockenzie more than  years ago, where he raised his family with we Ann.A consultant engineer, he ran his own successful business and still found the time to be an active member of his local community.He was a founding member of the tenantsrsquo and residentsrsquo association, which helped improve Whin Park for local families.Ward councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell said: ldquoLarry made a huge contribution to the tenantsrsquo and residentsrsquo association and the wider community. He understood and clearly articulated the interests of local people. He will be sorely missed.Laura Bishop from the campaign to reduce speeding at Avenue Road, outside The Chimneys, said: ldquoLarry was a lovely man who helped us with our campaign to make Avenue Road pelican crossing safer for the children using it to cross to get to school.ldquoSending condolences to his family.Mr Tomlins is survived by his we, his four children, his daughter-in-law and his two grandchildren.

title: haddington-florist-celebrates-40-years-in-bloom
story: Erica Muirhead opened her shop Ericarsquos on January , , becoming a key part of Haddingtonrsquos High Street.The business celebrated the th anniversary with Prosecco and cake and the owner said: ldquoIt does not seem like  years ndash it feels about ! When you look at it in black and white, it seems absurd.The business was originally based at  High Street before moving to its current home of  High Street in the early s.But Erica, who lives in the town, said her passion for flowers went back to before starting the business.She said: ldquoMy mum loved flower arranging and I used to go to the Haddington Floral Art Club.ldquoI would chum her along and I just really enjoyed it and I was fascinated with all the flowers and plants.ldquoWhen I got a job with Irene Spray, I found something that was just so interesting and every day was dferent in the shop.Looking back over the  years, Erica said much had changed, with a greater iety of flowers now on offer.She added: ldquoI do still enjoy coming in each day.ldquoI am very, very fortunate that I have got something that I love getting up for and out to in the morning. I love the customer contact and just the connection that you form on such a personal level.ldquoFlowers are sent for so many dferent occasions and it is just a lovely thing to be able to touch peoplersquos lives in that way.

title: dunbar-schoolboy-theo-foster-to-run-out-with-scotland-stars-at-murrayfield-on-saturday
story: Match mascot Theo Foster will run out alongside the Scotland team this weekend against Ireland in the second round of fixtures in the Six Nations.The youngster, who is in P at Dunbar Primary School, will be joined at Murrayfield Stadium by his mum Victoria and dad Andy.His dad, who is a support worker, told the Courier: ldquoTheo is absolutely buzzing.ldquoWe have had to scrape him off the ceiling and mum and dad are both excited as well.ldquoMy nephew Taylor Wilson, who is a great player, plays for Scotland Redsand is going to the match as well.ldquoOn the day, we have got to be there for pm and we meet the ladies that co-ordinate the mascots.ldquoThere will be great fun and they get to meet the players.ldquoObviously, they hold the playersrsquo hands and I have told Theo he needs to try to get [Scotland captain] Greig Laidlawrsquos hand.ldquoThey walk out onto the pitch, they run out, and he gets a Scotland tracksuit and top.ldquoThey will stand there for the national anthems giving it laldly before sitting with us in complimentary seats.ldquoAfter the final whistle, he will get autographs from the Scotland players and maybe the Irish players.Theo has been playing rugby since he was in P after linking up with Dunbar RFCrsquos youth system.The budding scrum-half, who lives in Dunbar, was part of the team that won the P  Cup, with the final played at Murrayfield during the clash between Edinburgh and Glasgow Warriors during the festive period.His dad said that the -year-old had tried his hand at football, karate, taekwondo and golf but found a real love for rugby.The names of youngsters at Dunbar RFC were put into a hat and it was Theo who had the luck as his name was pulled out in draw to find a mascot.David Wilson, chairman of the club, wished the family well for the match, which kicks off at .pm on Saturday.He said: ldquoIt is really good, it is a cracking thing.ldquoI know the last kid that did it thought it was really good.

title: strike-going-ahead-as-planned-at-queen-margaret-university
story: That cames after the University and College Unionsaid thattalks with QMU had"ended without a satisfactory resolution".If the dispute cannot be resolved then staff are due to walk out again on Monday and Wednesday next week.UCU members say tehy are are angry at the loss of about  jobs, which represents a loss of seven per centof the universityrsquos total workforce.The union argues thatthese job losses were unnecessary and will increase the workloads of remaining staff who will need to do more with less resources.In the recent strike ballot, two-thirds of UCU memberswho voted backed strike action on a turnout of  per cent.Oonagh OrsquoBrien, QMU UCU spokesperson, said: ldquoNobody wants to take strike actionbut the way the decisions to make cuts were made has angered staff and risks damaging the universityrsquos reputation and the student experience.ldquoThe level of support for strike action shows the strength of feeling about the cuts."The university needs to recognise how unhappy staff are and work with UCU to sort out a mess theyrsquove created.A spokesperson from Queen Margaret Universitysaid: ldquoWe advised all staff and students on Monday that we have reached a position where we have been able to achieve the level of cost savings required from the universityrsquos transformation project without the need to make any compulsory redundancies."We are pleased that, as a result of this, Unison agreed to withdraw planned strike action, but are disappointed that another trade union, UCU, has decided to proceed with strike action today .ldquoWe plan to operate classes as normal as far as possible today and on other proposed dates, and to minimise any disruption to students. Indeed, many of QMUrsquos staff are not members of UCU.ldquoUCUrsquos action is in response to the universityrsquos transformation project plans, which are designed to ensure that we can continue to lead inproviding relevant teaching and research, and in providing the supportive and stimulating learning environment of which we are so proud."The transformation project plans take account of extensive consultation with staff and trade unions over a number of months, and reflects their input wherever possible.

title: roadside-services-plan-for-former-raceland-site-approved
story: More than  jobs are expected to be created when Euro Garages opens its new service station on the site of the former Raceland karting centre, near Gladsmuir.And the company pledged to employ local people who were able to ldquowalk or cycle to work easily on the new development.It includes a -hour petrol station and fast food drive-thru, with additional fast food and coffee shop drive thrus open daily on the site.In a planning statement to East Lothian Council, Euro Garages stated that the site would be its first development to include a McDonaldrsquos franchise in it after creating a partnership with the burger chain.But at the start of the planning committee meeting where the plans were being decided on Tuesday, Euro Garages asked for the statement to be amended, stating they ldquodo not name brands at this stage.The international company has  Starbucks,  Burger Kings,  Subways and  Greggs bakeries already operating out of its sites across the UK and around the world.Tom Jeremiah, group planning director at Euro Garages Group, said: ldquoWe take our responsibility to local employment seriously and this development could deliver up to  jobs in a range of full and part-time roles.ldquoWe aim to employ people who can walk or cycle to work easily, prioritising local people and creating jobs for residents of East Lothian. This will support the local economy and ensure people donrsquot need to travel to Edinburgh to access employment opportunities.At the meeting, concerns were raised about a decision not to provide lorry parking at the site, despite offering lorries refuelling stations.Rob Buffham, Euro Garages planning manager, told the meeting: ldquoOur experience of other sites is HGV parking comes with a lot of problems. Local constabularies want CCTV and security fencing.ldquoIt is recognised by police these days that they are a focus for crime so we are not providing it.Councillor Norman Hampshire, planning convenor, raised concerns about the lack of a lorry park, pointing to the next stop point on the journey south at Asda, Dunbar, where there are also petrol filling services and a McDonaldrsquos.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoWe have problems with HGVs at the McDonaldrsquos at Asda where they park all over the place. We need to find a way for them to park safely without causing hazards to anyone .Councillor Sue Kempson said that while she would support the planning application, she was ldquovery upset about the attitude to the HGVs. She said: ldquoThere is an attitude of lsquowe do not want themrsquo ndash well you are going to get them.Mr Buffham highlighted that an access road leading to the pumps for HGVs had space for lorries to queue on the site.Euro Garages has already agreed to set aside part of the site which may be required to widen the country road to its east to serve the new Blindwells settlement planned for the area in the future.Mr Jeremiah said: ldquoThis is an important development for East Lothian and we are thrilled the council have approved our application.ldquoThere are only limited roadside services on this stretch of the A, and existing services are dated. They cannot offer the modern requirements motorists now demand, including electric vehicle charging points along with high-quality drive-thru retail.Mr Hampshire hoped that part of the land would eventually bring a motel to the site which he said would complete the services development. The plans were approved unanimously, with conditions added to increase the number of bicycle parking spots from  to  to accommodate large groups and ensure construction traffic only entered the site from the A access.

title: works-starts-in-belhaven-on-scotlands-first-surf-performance-centre
story: Belhaven Surf Centre Ltd was given the green light to open a lsquosurf hubrsquo on Belhavenrsquos Shore Road last May.Construction work on the building, which will be used by a number of community groups, got under way last week.Alasdair Swan, finance director for Belhaven Surf Centre, said: ldquoWork has now started. We are hoping that the building will be completed in mid-summer but like all these projects it is weather dependent. We are expecting to be open before the autumn.The two-storey building, which is expected to cost in the region of pound,, with funding provided by Leader, WREN, East Lothian Council, Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, BeGreen, Community Wind Farm and private donations, is the first of its kind in Scotland.As well as providing a home for Coast to Coast Surf School, it will be utilised by a number of other groups, including East Lothian Countryside Ranger Service, The Wave Project and Dunbar Surf Le Saving Club.Mr Swan said: ldquoThe surf centre is a community building.ldquoIt is currently not for profit but we hope to move it to full charitable status.ldquoIt exists to support the ious surfing organisations in Dunbar.ldquoDunbar is getting a growing reputation for wonderful surfing but does not have any facility to welcome people from around the world to Dunbar.Downstairs in the building, which measures  metres by  metres, will including a teaching room and small office.Changing rooms, hot showers and storage will also be included, with the upstairs featuring two meeting rooms, one of them available for hire by community groups, the other likely tobe leased toone of the local charities.Ward councillor Paul McLennan was pleased to see work starting. He said: ldquoI think it is fantastic, a great initiative and I think you are going to see more and more people there.Ward colleague Councillor Norman Hampshire was similarly pleased.He said: ldquoObviously, there has been a huge growth in the people coming to Dunbar and Belhaven Bay to do surfing.ldquoTo have this facility right on the beach area will be a huge benefit to all surfers coming to that area.

title: man-caught-drink-driving-for-the-third-time
story: John Mercer was stopped by police in a Musselburgh street, where he was found to be nearly five times over the drink-drive limit.Mercer, from Dalkeith, was found to have mg of alcohol in ml of breath when he was pulled over last June ndash the legal limit is mg in ml of breath.Defence solicitor Nigel Bruce told Edinburgh Sherf Court on Monday that Mercer, , turned to alcohol as he ldquoreacts badly to pressure.Sherf Adrian Cottam was also told this was the third time Mercer had been caught drink-driving.Sherf Cottam told Mercer he was being sentenced to carry out  hours of unpaid work and placed on  months of supervision as a direct alternative to custody.Mercer was also banned from driving for the next  months during Mondayrsquos hearing.Mercer admitted to driving a vehicle with mg of alcohol in ml of breath at North High Street, Musselburgh, on June  last year.

title: tims-tales-a-little-can-be-a-lot
story: FINALLY we have reached the time of year when people finishing work at pm can go home in daylight. But spring still feels like a long way off.I crave it, not just because it makes the evening walks in the woods possible once more, but because of the beauty it s to the landscape.The land is still dormant, with nature seemingly sleeping. Itrsquos at this time of year that the ugly results of peoplersquos disregard for the land can be most clearly seen. Litter of all kinds lsquodecoratesrsquo the roadsides. In summer it is partly hidden as hedges, roadside bushes and grasses grow. But in winter nature retreats and exposes the extent of peoplersquos uncaring behaviour.I canrsquot understand it, I really canrsquot. Our country is so beautul, yet so many people just throw rubbish from their car window. Do they not see the results and feel a sense of shame and horror  In a country where we have the facilities to dispose of our rubbish, there is simply no excuse to trash our landscape like this.And in a time when there are cuts to vital services, councils having to pay money to pick up peoplersquos rubbish from the sides of roads is just another unseen effect. Itrsquos not just that itrsquos ugly to look at, itrsquos polluting our environment, killing wildle and leaving an appalling legacy for our children.And so as we set off last Sunday for a walk, the sight of litter strewn everywhere along the roadside was quite depressing. And my children noticed its ugliness too. ldquoWhy do people litter like this  I was asked by my five-year-old Skye, and to be honest I struggled for an answer.ldquoI really donrsquot know, but it must be because they donrsquot care.My daughter seemed forlorn at this reply as we drove past a mass of discarded fast food remains, plastic bottles, beer bottles, plastic bags and yet more fast food rubbish.But I wanted to lt her spirits and so told her we were going on a hunt for something beautul. We were on a snowdrop hunt! And so as we drove to our destination, I reminded them of my version of the old story:lsquoMany years ago, Snow had no colour. It felt ashamed and left out to be colourless, especially when the land was so beautully covered in flowers of all dferent colours.And so Snow asked the flowersthey would be willing to share just a little of their colour. First Snow asked the daffodils, who were a beautul yellow. But they said no, they needed all their colour for themselves.Then Snow asked the bluebells, who were a wonderful blue. But they said they were too small to share any of their colour.Then Snow asked the whin bushesthey could share some of their vivid yellow, and they said no because they needed the colour.Snow even asked the roses of summer, but got the same answer: no.Then Snow heard a small voice and looked down. It was a small white flower. We can share some of our colour, with you it said.ldquoBut you are so small and you need your colour for yourself, said Snow. ldquoYes, the flower replied, ldquowe are small and we need our colour, but there are many of us andeach one of us gives a little then we can give you enough colour.ldquoThat is very kind of you but I donrsquot want to ruin your beautul appearance, said Snow.ldquoDonrsquot worry, said the wee white flower, ldquowe can all take a little colour from the inside of our petals, so it will not be noticed that any white is missing.rsquoAnd so that is how Snow became white. And because of the kindness shown by this little flower, Snow agreed to share its name with it, and so they became known as snowdrops.Snow also shared its space with the wee flower, so snowdrops and snow are often seen on the ground together. Andyou look carefully inside the snowdrop, you will see the hidden part where the white has been scraped off to give to Snow.With the storyrsquos end we arrived at Smeaton Lake, near East Linton, our destination for the snowdrop hunt. Itrsquos such a beautul place where a planted wood stands guard by a lake created  years ago. The woodland here is possibly unsurpassed in East Lothian for the canopy of snowdrops it displays.Excited screams at small patches of the flower soon gave way to ldquowow, look as we reached the end of the waterside and a wood carpeted by the wee flowers.My spirits were lted as I watched my daughter carefully examine flowers for evidence they had shared their colour. She showed her wee brother the green strips inside, explaining that is where the white was shared from. Both were careful not to damage or pick the flowers, despite their desire to do so.ldquoWersquoll find some growing in a less happy place and take those ones home, I assured them.And so we eventually headed back, a delicious bowl of ice cream at The Goth in Prestonpans, accompanied by traditional music, the reward for a good dayrsquos hunting.That night my daughter was reflective. ldquoI wish people wouldnrsquot spoil nature, she said. I felt guilty shersquos only five, I thought to myself, and shouldnrsquot have to be concerned about such things at that age. Perhaps I should have kept my thoughts to myself.ldquoBut I wonrsquot, and Irsquoll tell my friends not to as well. Can you tell me the snowdrop story again  So I told her the story once more.She had one wee snowdrop in a bowl by her bed. We had found it growing precariously at the verge of the road, surrounded by litter, and she wanted to lsquosaversquo it. So we did, hopefully with roots intact.ldquoWell we will plant the snowdrop in the garden and perhaps we will have our own snowdrops next year! I said to her, and she was happy at this.I went downstairs as she slept. My thoughts and emotions flooded me. My anger and depression at the ignorant mess we are making of our planet was superseded by my daughterrsquos determination to make a small dference, just like the snowdrop in the story.And perhaps therein lies the true message of that old tale: a dference can be made,we all do a little, but do it together.The children are the future, but letrsquos not leave all our ugly mess and destruction to our children to deal with. Let us all do something small, as many already are, to change the way we behave and how we appreciate what we have been gted.For our childrenrsquos sake, I really hope itrsquos not too late.

title: county-team-conquer-kilimanjaro-in-memory-of-vera-cameron
story: Dougie Cameron and daughter Laura-Jane were joined by seven other men and women in climbing Mount Kilimanjaro last week.The trek was the latest fundraiser in memory of Vera Cameron and in aid of Cancer Research UK.Laura-Jane said that her mum would have thought the fundraisers were ldquooff our heads but would be ldquoreally proud of their achievement, which takes the fundraising total to about pound,.She said: ldquoIt was a really tough challenge but the fact we were doing it for charity kept us going.ldquoAt the end of the day, it was for such a good cause and we wanted to get to the top and keep the sponsorship going.ldquoThe whole experience was totally dferent to what I expected.ldquoBeing over seven days, we have never done anything like that before and it was tough mentally and physically.ldquoWe had one goal ndash to get to the summit ndash and we ended up making lots of new friends and spent a lot of time with other groups.ldquoIt was a really good experience overall.Vera, of Macmerry, worked for East Lothian Council as a senior administrator in transportation.Dougie, who is site attendant at Kinwegar Recycling Centre in Wallyford, was joined by seven colleagues from the council on the memorable trip.Laura-Jane, , and her dad set off from Scotland on January  alongside Ray Montgomery , Paul Ritchie , Lorraine Faulds , William Kelley , Stuart Baxter , Rachael Cormackand Vanessa Sanal .The group began the trip up the near-,-metre-high mountain on the Saturday and reached the summit last Thursday.Then it was back down before flying home on Sunday and back to work on Monday.Laura-Jane, who works as a PR officer, said it was ldquosurreal to think that just a few days earlier she had been standing at the top of Kilimanjaro.Already, more than pound, has been donated to the good cause, with that figure set to rise to pound, when all the money has been donated and counted.Previously, fundraisers have completed a number of other challenges ndash although nothing on the scale of the latest achievement ndash in memory of Vera, who was  when she passed away from cancer in .The West Highland Way, which stretches from Milngavie to Fort William , and the Three Peaks Challenge, which sees the highest peaks in Scotland, England and Wales ndash Ben Nevis, Scafell Pike and Snowdon respectively ndash climbed have been completed.Laura-Jane, who lives in Tranent, said: ldquoI think my mum would think we were off our heads for doing what we have done but really proud of us. We are keeping her memory alive and raising so much money for a really good cause.To make a donation, go to justgiving fundraising vera-kilimanjaro

title: noodle-bus-to-be-based-at-east-linton-mart
story: Plans to site the vehicle, which will be transformed into a noodle bar, at East Linton Mart were given the go-ahead by East Lothian Council.The approval came despite two objections, including from the local community council.Dunbar-based company Wok N Go Noodle Bar plans to transform the ground floor of the bus into a kitchen and food preparation area.Upstairs will be used by customers, with the bus capable of serving  diners.Plans suggest the bus would be open from .pm to pm between Sunday and Thursday, and open an hour later on Fridays and Saturdays.The bus would also be open from noon to pm during the Sunday Market at The Mart, off Station Road.Concerns about the plans included that the bright yellow bus was not in keeping with the historic site and a lack of detail about how the venture would operate.But the council planning officerrsquos report noted: ldquoThe proposed bus for use as a noodle bar would be positioned on the site such that by virtue of the positioning and orientation of the windows and doors on it would not give rise to any harmful overlooking of any nearby residential properties.ldquoGiven the proposed noodle bar is to be located within a double-decker bus which is not designed for permanent use or permanent siting and it is to be located within a prominent location within East Linton, it would be prudent for any grant of planning permission for it to be for a temporary period.A condition has been attached to the planning permission which states that permission has been given for two years, although this could be extended.The historic auction mart was traditionally a bustling agricultural centre for East Linton.However, in recent years it has been transformed and become home to The Mart Farm Shop and Cafe and also Viarama, which is Scotlandrsquos first virtual reality company and social enterprise.In addition, regular farmersrsquo markets are held at the site, as well as car boot sales, coffee mornings and classes.

title: traders-vow-to-keep-dunbar-high-street-viable-if-asda-expands
story: Asda Stores Limited wants to increase the size of its Spott Road store, which opened more than a decade ago.The additional space, which would be to the north of the existing building, would allow for more homeware to be stocked, alongside the creation of a home shopping service.Dunbar Tradesrsquo Associationstrongly opposed the supermarket when it was first proposed.DTA members met recently and discussed the supermarket giantrsquos plans for expansion, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.A DTA spokeswoman said: ldquoDunbar Tradesrsquo Association discussed the proposed expansion of Asda and, even though we have had no official communication, we feel that Asda serves a purpose within the community.ldquoHigh Street is the backbone of our community and we are very, very proud of High Street and the independent retail shops that we offer.ldquoWe have to ensure that our High Street remains so.Currently, the store has a floorspace of about ,m, with the extension adding a further m to the building.The proposed extension would result in  parking spaces being lost.However, the plans suggest that the  remaining spaces would be adequate because the increase in home delivery trips would offset the reduction in customer trips to the store.The proposals show that four vans are expected to operate from the store, with one van making four delivery trips per day and the remaining three vans doing half that amount.A number of Dunbarrsquos community councillors have met with Asda representatives about the proposals.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, said ldquogenerally, we were very supportive of it.She added: ldquoIt is a very relatively modest extension.ldquoIt is predominantly houseware and they are going to run their home shopping service from there with potentially another  jobs.ldquoAt the moment, home deliveries come out of Edinburgh.The supermarket, which forms part of a development off Spott Road, which also includes a petrol station, the Pine Marten hotel and restaurant, and McDonaldrsquos restaurant, was given the go-ahead in .At that time, many traders predicted it would have a serious impact on businesses in the town centre.Mrs Swan added: ldquoOur understanding is their offer is not one that is going to conflict with High Street.

title: single-primary-school-plan-for-prestonpans-to-go-ahead
story: The proposal to close the two schools and establish a new primary school covering nursery to P, operating from the existing school sites, followed a public consultation.Councillors agreed to progress the plans at a meeting of East Lothian Council on December .This decision needed to be ratied by Scottish Ministers.The new school will follow a single curriculum and a single headteacher will be appointed to oversee its management.The school structure in the town currently has nursery to P children attending the infant school before transferring to the primary school for P to P however, both schools operate their own curriculums independently.Fiona Robertson, the councilrsquos head of education, said: ldquoPrestonpans is the only area in East Lothian where nursery to P and P-P are taught across two schools.ldquoWe believe having one primary school, working under a single management structure, will benefit pupils at all levels of their learning as it does where in the county by ensuring a smoother progression through school and better coherence across the curriculum at all ages and stages.ldquoEducation Scotland has recognised the potential educational benefits and opportunities for greater coherence in the curriculum.ldquoWe have written to staff and parents to advise them of this decision. Our priority now is to work with the headteachers and the parent council chairs in both schools, and to support staff, parents and pupils during the move.

title: substance-sprayed-into-childs-face-in-tranent
story: The incident took place outside Asda on Haddington Road between .pm and pm on Friday.One of a group of four males, described as being about  years old and all wearing hoodies, sprayed a substance on the face and clothing of a -year-old girl as she walked with her friend.The victim was not injured but the substance did cause discolouration to her clothes.Enquiries so far suggest that the substance may have been antreeze.Detective Constable Mandy Cummings of Dalkeith CID said: "There was no interaction between the teenagers and the victim beforehand, so this is believed to have been opportunistic and potentially thought of as a prank by those involved."However, this behaviour is absolutely unacceptable and this incident is being treated as an assault."Thankfully, the girl was uninjured but this understandably caused concern and upset to her and her family."Anyone who may have seen the teenagers in the area, or who has any information about this incident, is urged to come forward and report this."Contact Police Scotland on  with information, quoting incident number  ofFebruary , or contact the charity Crimestoppers anonymously on   .

title: strikes-called-off-at-queen-margaret-university
story: Agreement between the University and College Union and QMU will ensure there will be no compulsory redundancies and no plans for further staff cuts.They are committed to work together on a number of other workplace issues.A joint statement also addresses how workloads will be managed and notes the trade union voice as being "valued and integral to the university".Oonagh OrsquoBrien, the universitys UCU spokesperson, said: "This has been a dficult time and staff have been deeply worried about their jobs and frustrated at the way changes have been made."This agreement means there will be no compulsory redundancies and ensures that changes due to reduced staff will be managed."It also allows us to move forward and work together to improve our workplace policies for the future."A spokesperson from Queen Margaret University said: "QMU management and UCU have reached an agreement to resolve the trade dispute between UCU and QMU."Strike action and action short of a strike have been called off with immediate effect."Both parties are pleased to have reached an agreement and are fully committed to rebuilding positive collective bargaining."A series of strikes, including one on Wednesday, were planned over job losses at the university after union bosses said talks had "ended without a satisfactory resolution".UCU members previously said they were angry at the loss of about  jobs, which represented a loss of seven per cent of the universityrsquos total workforce.In a recent strike ballot, two-thirds of UCU memberswho voted had backed strike action on a turnout of  per cent.

title: five-per-cent-rent-rise-in-east-lothian-is-approved
story: An annual rent rise of five per cent, approved by East Lothian Council this week, on top of the decision to increase council tax to the maximum . per cent, will see tenantsrsquo costs increase.SNP councillor Neil Gilbert claimed on Twitter the decision would hit tenants in Band D housing with additional bills of pound in the coming year.His claim came after the SNP Group called on the councilrsquos administration to reduce the proposed rent increase for the coming year to . per cent ndash inflation plus one per cent.The annual rent review proposed continuing with the yearly five per cent rise, which has been approved at every budget since , for another five years.Putting forward an amendment to the rent increase, Councillor Stuart Currie, leader of the SNP Group, argued that a lower increase was fairer given peoplersquos current wages.Mr Currie said: ldquoIt takes into account what people are seeing in wages and other payments they receive. It still maintainsthe surplus in housing accounts.East Lothian Council carried out a public consultation among residents who were asked whether they agreed with a five per cent increase in the coming years. Of the  per cent of council tenants who responded, a massive  per cent backed the increase.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, housing convenor, said tenants had given their support to the increase.He said: ldquoIt will still mean East Lothian will remain one of the lowest rents in Scotland.He also pointed out it would allow for poundmillion to be spent on modernisation and extensions of council properties in the coming year and poundmillion for new council housing.Councillor Jane Henderson, Conservative Leader of the Opposition, said that while the SNPrsquos proposal was a ldquovery reasonable representation, she would support the administrationrsquos five per cent increase.

title: ae-waits-at-worst-level-for-15-years
story: Figures from NHS England show that, during January, just .% of patients were treated or admitted in four hours, against a % target.This meansnearly , patients waited longer than they should, and comes despite lower levels of flu and norovirus than last year.The data shows that , people in January endured very long waits ndash often called trolley waits ndash to be admitted to hospital.After a decision had been taken to admit them, this group waited four hours or more before a ward bed was found for them.The last time the % target ndash which was introduced in  ndash was hit was in July .Nuffield Trust chief economist Professor John Appleby said:ldquoTodayrsquos figures remind us that the NHS is fighting a losing battle in trying to meet its commitments to provide timely healthcare in the face of the pressure it is under.ldquoThere is a risk that we lose sight of these problems as Brexit distracts us, or become numbed as we forget the last time targets were met.ldquoBut this situation has a serious impact on hundreds of thousands of patients, and will be demoralising for many staff.ldquoThe proportion of patients spending more than four hours in AE has risen to .% in January ndash the highest ever in this set of data.ldquoIt looks like the gap between the servicersquos capacity and the care we need from it is widening.He said only two AE departments in England met the four-hour target and attendances have risen by an ldquoastonishing , compared with January last year, at a time in the year when they would usually fall.ldquoLast year, there was widespread concern as we saw trolley waits balloon, yet todayrsquos figures show an even higher level, he said.Royal College of Emergency Medicinepresident, Dr Taj Hassan, said: ldquoSadly the situation afflicting our emergency departments has become seemingly normalised with a lsquochronic crisis modersquothat does not allow staff to deliver the quality of care they would wish and patients should rightly expect.ldquoThe evidence on resultant crowding in departments is clear ndash it adds to the risk of harm to patients leading to excess deaths and disability.ldquoThese figures make clear the true scale of this crisis facing our systems.Shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth said:ldquoAE waiting times are now at their worst level since records began, which is a damning indictment of years of austerity and wider cuts imposed upon health and care services under the Tories.ldquoMinisterial incompetence has left our NHS with chronic shortages of NHS staff with no clear idea of how to sort this out.Patricia Marquis, director of the Royal College of Nursingin England, said of trolley waits:ldquoNo nurse ever wants to leave patients on trolleys in corridors or waiting for hours in an armchair when therersquos no bed.But she added: ldquoItrsquos not just about beds, we also need the nurses to safely staff them.A spokesman for the NHS said thousands more people have been successfully treated in AE within four hours than last year.This is because the total number of attendances has gone up year on year.He said an average , more people a day were assessed, treated and discharged or admitted from AE within four hours in January  compared with the same month in  ndash an increase of .%.Miriam Deakin, director of policy and strategy at NHS Providers, said demand for care had put signicant strain on trusts and staff but the NHS was treating more patients.She added: ldquoThis is largely down to the work trusts have been doing to improve patient flow and reducing the time patients spend in hospital.ldquoImproved joined-up working with partners in the community and primary care is also helping to support trusts to manage demand better.For planned care, the NHS data shows that the proportion of people waiting more than  weeks for treatment is at its highest level for a decade.December figures show there were , people waiting more than  weeks for treatment.Some % of all patients should be treated within  weeks but this has not been met since February .The data also shows that it is more than three years since the NHS last met the target for patients urgently referred with cancer to start treatment within two months.The RCEM, which represents , emergency medicine clinicians, opposes NHS Englandrsquos plan to alter the four-hour target.NHS England is currently reviewing its clinical targets including the requirement that % of all patients attending AE are treated, admitted or discharged within four hours.NHS England chief executive Simon Stevens has said a new target willsee a shorter waiting time target for treating people with serious conditions such as stroke, heart attack and sepsis.People with less critical needs will need to wait longer.The RCEM has saidremoving the current four-hour target ldquowill have a near-catastrophic impact on patient safety.

title: brexit-live-testing-day-for-may-ahead-of-next-commons-vote
story: Eurosceptic Conservatives could vote against or abstain on the Governmentrsquos motion, which Tory critics insist effectively means the Prime Minister is abandoning a no-deal exit option.Ahead of the main vote, three amendments have been selected which could also hamper the Governmentrsquos plans, although these votes are not legally binding.The Speaker has provisionally selected the following amendments to todays #BrexitNextSteps motion:ndash @jeremycorbyn ndash @IanBlackfordMP ndash @Anna_Soubry Read all amendments here: https:t.co GDlfYJLDwL pic QqIUOursKmdash UK House of CommonsFebruary , .pmEuropean Research Group chairman Jacob Rees-Mogg said it was ldquohighly unlikely that eurosceptic Tories would vote against the Government in Thursday eveningrsquos votes.Mr Rees-Mogg told ITV News: ldquoTodayrsquos business is not fundamentally important. It is all about where the Government is going.ldquoThis is a secondary issue, rather than a primary one, and that is why I think it is highly unlikely people will be voting against this motion.Could the ERG rebellion be over Jacob Rees-Mogg tells @PaulBrandITV why he thinks its highly unlikely people will be voting against the government Brexit motion: https:t.co qItFAoAL pic QsVvtDaUQmdash ITV NewsFebruary , .pmMeanwhile in Dublin, Irish premier Leo Varadkar denied being ldquocomplacent over the UK crashing out of the EU.He said: ldquoAs we are not certain we have put enormous preparations into making sure that Ireland is as ready as we can be for a no-deal, so this is not complacency, but it is competence.ldquoIreland certainly wants an orderly Brexit, rather than an disorderly one, the UK does too, so does the EU.ldquoWhen everybody wants that to happen we will work extremely hard to achieve that but donrsquot think for a second that is complacency at all. We are making all the preparations for a no-deal.pmSir Keir said MPs must now put a ldquohard stopto running down the clock and so Labour will back the Yvette Cooper amendment later this month calling for an extension to Article  in the event of no deal being agreed by mid-March.ldquoThe simple fact is this, we canrsquot declare that we are against a no-deal outcome and then do nothing, he said.ldquoThe Government is failing to act so we must act, hence the next step is to ensure a hard stop to running down the clock to ensure that on th February the Prime Minister must either put her deal or allow Parliament to decide what happens next.ldquoI would hope that anyone who genuinely opposes no deal would see that an extension by that date, th March, is unavoidable..pmSir Keir Starmer came under pressure from his own party colleagues to confirm holding another referendum on the Brexit deal would now be the next step for Labour.Labour MP Ben Bradshawurged him to act sooner rather than later andsaid: ldquoThe Government has clearly rejected Labourrsquos offer of a less damaging Brexit and to wait until the end of March to activate our unanimously agreed conference policy in favour of a public vote would be far, far too late.Sir Keir admitted the Prime Minister had been ldquonon-committal but said discussions continued, although he refused to disclose details as they were ldquoconfidential.He added: ldquoThere must come a point where the options are claried and reduced, then voted upon, and I agree with that proposition and it needs to be done before the end of March..pm.pmWallasey Labour MP Angela Eagle intervened in Sir Keirrsquos speech, saying: ldquoIs he not as astonished as I am that we have a Prime Minister and a Government that are willing to play this kind of reckless gamble with the future prosperity of our country just to keep their rotten party together.Sir Keir replied: ldquoWell it is a gamble.He added: ldquoThe plan is to put essentially the same deal back to this House as a binary choice, my deal or no deal. Perhaps with some additional words which the attorneycan say have real signicance, but it will be essentially the same deal. That is not holding your nerve, that is plain reckless and we have to say no..pmSir Keir drew on his past dealings with the PM as he said he did not think Mrs May would take the UK out of the EU without a deal because of her ldquodeep sense of duty.The former Director of Public Prosecutions said he had worked with Mrs May when she was Home Secretary, saying she had a ldquodeep sense of duty, adding: ldquoAnd deep down I do not think that this Prime Minister will take us out of the EU on the th of March, and thatrsquos the basis that we should be having this conversation.Sir Keir also suggested the likelihood of getting an improved deal which fixes the issues some MPs have with the backstop before we are due to exit the EU are ldquoslim.The shadow Brexit secretary said: ldquoThe simple and painful truth is thisthere had been a viable alternative to the backstop there would never have been a backstop..pmShadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer urged MPs not to be ldquofooled the Prime Minister was continuing to negotiate in earnest.He said: ldquoIt is obvious what the Prime Minister is up to ndash she is pretending to make progress while running down the clock.ldquoA non-update every other week to buy another two weeks of process, inching ever closer to the th March deadline in  days. We should not be fooled.Shadow Brexit Secretary, @Keir_Starmer is speaking in favour of @jeremycorbyns amendment to the #BrexitNextSteps motion, Amendment .We asked why this amendment has been put forward. pic EcEYfGXuBvmdash UK House of CommonsFebruary , .pmMr Barclay said the Malthouse Compromise had been ldquotaken forward with the EU and raised with the EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier, who had ldquoinitial concerns.Tory MP Charlie Elphickeasked  the so-called alternative arrangements were ldquonow Government policy and asked ldquowill he take a fully worked up proposal to the EU as part of negotiations.Mr Barclay said: ldquoWe have taken it forward with the EU ndash I have raised it with Michel Barnier and I will be discussing it again with him.The Malthouse Compromise contains two choices to be offered to the EU: one for how the UK will leave with a deal, and one for how it will leave without. Plan A is similar to the current Withdrawal Agreement, but with changes to the Irish backstop and the implementation period. Plan B assumes that agreement on the Withdrawal Agreement is not possible and creates a ldquotransitional standstill period.pmReferring to the position of European leaders, Mr Barclay said: ldquoIf the EU were to make changes to the backstop, whether that would enable a deal to passhellip That is why itrsquos important a clear message is sent from this House as part of those negotiations.ldquoColleagues should be in no doubt that the EU will be watching our votes tonight carefully for any sign that our resolve is weakening..pmMr Barclay said the desire for a deal was shared by many across the EU ldquobecause they recognise that no deal is in neither sidersquos interests. They recognise that no deal is disruptive.DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds intervened: ldquoOf course we want to get a deal with the EU, but isnrsquot it the case thatyou take no deal off the table thatrsquos the surest way of ensuring the other side dig in on their current positionhellip ldquoSo those who call for no deal to be taken off the table are actually playing into the hands of the possibility of a no deal.No news is not always good news. EU still waiting for concrete, realistic proposals from London on how to break #Brexit impasse. pic vcDlAJeAnmdash Donald TuskFebruary , .pmOpening the debate the Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay said Theresa May must be given more time to take ldquoParliamentrsquos mandate for a deal to the EU.He said: ldquoOn the th of January a majority of honourable and right honourable members told this House, and our country, that they would support a deal.ldquoBut this support was conditional, that members were prepared to compromise on issues but not on the overriding issue of the backstop.Mr Barclay said todayrsquos motion confirms the Commonsrsquo support for Sir Graham Bradyrsquos amendment which was passed last month, which ldquoin effect gives this Government an instruction which has been taken to our European partners.He added it is ldquoclear the priority is to address the indefinite nature of the backstop..pmCommons Speaker John Bercow has selected three amendments for consideration:ndash Amendment A, Labourrsquos proposal to push Theresa May to either put her Brexit deal to a Commons vote by February  or give Parliament the opportunity to take control of the process.ndash Amendment I, the SNP push to extend the Article  period.ndash Amendment E, Tory former minister Anna Soubry, joined by colleagues and MPs from other parties, with a proposal for the Government to publish within seven days the most recent official briefing document, relating to business and trade, on the implications of a no-deal Brexit presented to Cabinet.
