title: irish-government-not-complacent-over-no-deal-brexit-says-varadkar
story: Leo Varadkar said the Irish Government has put in ldquoenormous preparations for a no-deal Brexit.Following reports that the Taoiseach said he ldquoexpects the UK to leave the EU by the end of March with an agreement, Mr Varadkar said on Thursday that no one can be ldquoabsolutely sure a Brexit deal will be agreed.Speaking at the official sod-turning ceremony for a new second runway at Dublin Airport, he said: ldquoAs we are not certain, we have put enormous preparations into making sure that Ireland is as ready as we can be for a no deal, so this is not complacency, but it is competence.ldquoIreland certainly wants an orderly Brexit, rather than an disorderly one. The UK does too, so does the EU.ldquoWhen everybody wants that to happen we will work extremely hard to achieve that, but donrsquot think for a second that is complacency at all. We are making all the preparations for a no deal.ldquoWe will have the legislation at Cabinet on Tuesday, publish it next week, making the adjustments we have to make here at Dublin Airport, Dublin Port and Rosslare.ldquoLots of other things are happening to prepare the country for no deal.

title: its-been-unbelievable-scots-comic-des-clarke-on-learning-to-swim-drive-and-ride-a-bike-in-the-past-year
story: When I sat down with him two weeks ago, Des had just passed his driving test ndash hersquos .ldquoFor me itrsquos been the most unbelievable year. says Des.ldquoThis year marks about  months since I did Des Clarkersquos triathlon where I had to learn basic skills that I should have learned as a child ndash driving, swimming and cycling.ldquoItrsquos just been me looking at my le going lsquowhat happened rsquoldquoSo, what Irsquove done is broken myself down and built myself back up again.This is what Desrsquo show lsquoBrokenrsquo is all about, sorting his le out.ldquoThe show is at The Garage which is good, it seems like the right place for a new driver to end up at.ldquoGlasgow has proper Scottish people ndash I love Edinburgh and have done the Fringe. Edinburghrsquos good at attracting tourists, which is good, you get a good feeling for how funny yoursquod beyou were gigging in Paraguay but therersquos also something about seeing how funny you are in Possil.According to Des, lsquoBrokenrsquo involves getting a lot off his chest. After doing stand-up, the breakfast show, and writing TV and radio shows, therersquos a lot which Des never got round to doing.ldquoIrsquove probably had this attitude of lsquoI donrsquot need to do thatrsquo says Des.ldquoI can get places without driving, so I donrsquot. Irsquom not a fish so I donrsquot need to swim.ldquoTherersquos also an element of the older you get, the more scared you get because you deal with the consequences.ldquoWhen yoursquore learning to drive when yoursquore older itrsquos dferent. You think lsquowhatI die ndash Irsquove got a mortgage, whorsquos gonna pay for that rsquo When yoursquore  you donrsquot care.ldquoMy dad was a brickie, so was a really practical guy and then therersquos me ndash I talk for a living, thatrsquos not work, thatrsquos a hobby. I think I took his work ethic with me, but none of his skills.ldquoI want to say there was a great epiphany with a guy coming out of the clouds and saying lsquoDes, sort your le outrsquo, but it was more me waking up and being fed up of making excuses.Des has always been a comedian in some form or another, before working on the breakfast show at Capital, stand-up was his main passion, even from a young age.The focus was always on what he knows and loves, rather than learning something new.ldquoMy focuses would be other stuff: comedy, work, and just staying alive ndash maybe in that order, staying alive a distant third. Says Des.ldquoIrsquod always watch comedy shows as a kid and try and guess the punchline. When people watch TV or see shows as a pastime, I think I should claim that as a taxable benefit when I was a kid, because it was definitely research.ldquoDoing a radio show every day takes up a lot of time. Getting up at , therersquos just me, the milkman, some foxes and people crying coming out of casinos.ldquoIn the last year Irsquove developed a le. Irsquom much happier ndash I work just the same but I schedule in a lot more.The last few months have seen other changes in his le. Des is recently orced, and the dating scene has changed in the many years since he was a single man.ldquoDating again is alien to me, says Des.ldquoLast time I dated there were no apps. Itrsquos been good fun and a learning experience ndash but Irsquove not gone on the apps. I should, but I just donrsquot want a stranger swiping me. I also know someone will come up to you and say lsquoI saw you on Tinderrsquo ndash itrsquos a bit dferent to lsquoI saw you on the tellyrsquo.ldquoItrsquos more old-school, itrsquos going on nights out and meeting people and trying to talk to people.ldquoBut itrsquos been a total learning experience ndash itrsquos feels like a job interview where yoursquore not guaranteed to get a job in the end.ldquoI used to have this idea that it was better that they didnrsquot know who I am or what I do, then a few of my mates said to me lsquo I were you, thatrsquos exactly what Irsquod use to get datesrsquoldquoBut you see through that very quickly, and now Irsquom a lot more comfortable in my own skin. After five or  minutes, you either get on with someone or you donrsquot.ldquoI know so many people who pretend they do dferent jobs and pretend stuff about themselves that arenrsquot true, and then hope by the time they tell the partner the truth, theyrsquore already married with three kids.Des Clarke will perform Broken at Garage on March - as part of Whyte  Mackay Glasgow International Comedy Festival.

title: Iain Macwhirter  After making demands she couldn t accept  Corbyn has made Theresa May an offer she can   t refuse
story: Last week, Corbyn made a remarkable overture to the Prime Minister. He effectively dropped his opposition to her Withdrawal Agreement, which Labour had repeatedly condemned as the ldquoworst of all worlds. The Labour leaderrsquos letter still calls for a customs union, regulatory alignment on trade and guarantees on workers rights and security cooperation. But, crucially, Labour is no longer holding to the ldquosix tests, and insisting a Brexit deal should deliver ldquoexactly the same benefits as being in the single market.Labour has even dropped its opposition to the Irish backstop, which Mr Corbyn condemned, as recently as December, for leaving Britain ldquoin an indefinite halfway house with no say on its future. The explanatory note that Labour circulated after the leaderrsquos letter to May is quite clear. ldquoAny withdrawal agreement," it says, ldquowill need to include a backstop." Labour is also hinting at further compromises in ldquonegotiations.Hitherto, Labourrsquos policy has been to make demands May could never accept now they are trying to make her an offer she canrsquot refuse.So at last, after months of there being nothing much new to say about Brexit, suddenly we have what looks like a breakthrough, a historic compromise. Of course, you canrsquot overestimate the ability of political leaders to look a gt horse in the mouth. Theresa May may be so wedded to being a ldquobloody dficult womanthat she may find a way to avoid accepting Labourrsquos free hooved mammal. But the deal is there to be made.Senior Tories like Sir Oliver Letwin have welcomed the Labour offer, seeing it as a step towards a Norway-style agreement, even though it isnrsquot. Labourrsquos plan is much closer to Turkey, which is also in a customs union and accepts regulatory alignment. Brussels likes Corbyns proposals too, as a way out of hard Brexit ldquohell.Ive argued that the logic of Labourrsquos position was always to back something resembling Theresa Mayrsquos deal with the EU. It corresponds to Labourrsquos manesto commitments to leaving the EU, including the single market, and ending free movement while seeking frictionless trade. Mrs May has always supported regulatory alignment, since the ldquocommon rule book in her Chequers plan. And the backstop, remember, involves the UK remaining in the customs union until there is a future comprehensive trade deal.In what could almost have been a coordinated intervention last week, Mrs May restated in Dublin her determination to prevent a hard border in Ireland. This put the wind up the DUP, since they fear that the border might now move to the Irish Sea.It didnrsquot appeal to the hardline Brexiteers in her own party either, who are adamant that no deal is better than her bad deal. They thought it had been killed off by last monthrsquos record-breaking Commons defeat ndash but it may now live again with Labourrsquos backing.They canrsquot admit it, of course, but May and Corbyn are now speaking broadly the same language. The customs union, regulatory alignment, rights and protections etc are all matters to do with the future trade relationship with the EU, not the Withdrawal Agreement. It covers only money, citizenship and the Good Friday Agreement.The trading relationship can only be negotiated after Brexit. It is to be hammered out within the up to four years of the transition period, during which the UK remains in the single market and the customs union.Onlythere is no agreement does the backstop comes into play, and that really just extends the transition period indefinitely. May has said she will get assurances that the backstop will be time-limited, but she canrsquot get that from the European Union. If it was limited, it would no longer be a backstop.What hard Brexiteers really fear is that the transition period might lead to a soft Brexit, not a clean break ndash and they are right. What we know is that MPs will block any no-deal Brexit. Hardliners face a choice of May Corbyn or no Brexit at all.To secure a Commons majority without them, Mrs May could promise legislation to keep Britain in regulatory alignment with the customs union until a new trade deal is finalised ndash one which delivers the same benefits. This is anyway implicit in her promises to keep trade ldquofrictionless. Indeed, remaining in a customs union is the only way of achieving this. Up to now, she hasnrsquot been able to say this openly for fear of a rebellion by her hardline backbenchers, led by Jacob Rees-Mogg. They want a managed no-deal now, or in four years, under the so-called ldquoMalthouse Plan.Butshe has an ounce of political sense, May will now face them down and pivot to Labourrsquos softish Brexit. Labourrsquos demand that she put the customs union in primary legislation can be finessed, because the trade negotiations canrsquot happen until after Brexit. She doesnrsquot even need to ensure that Labour votes with her. Labour could abstain in the meaningful vote and achieve essentially the same result. The DUP would accept the customs union as a guarantee against a backstop or an east west hard border.Jeremy Corbyn could explain Labourrsquos abstention, which will be attacked by Vote Leave MPs andleader writers, by saying, as his spokespeople did last week: that the top priority ldquofor the nation is to avoid a no-deal. Corbynite commentators can be relied upon to condemn any Labour MPs who continue to vote against Mayrsquos deal as traitors. Unreconstructed Blairites, voting with the hated Moggists to force a no-deal disaster.Corbynrsquos letter made no reference to a Peoples Vote. Remainers in the Labour Party realise where all this is heading, which is why a number, like former shadow cabinet figures like Owen Smith, and Clive Lewis, have threatened to leave the party. That could become part of the script.Corbyn has used the Brexit issue to smoke out Blairite Remainers like Chuka Umunna, and the Jewish MP, Luciana Berger, in order to portray them as disloyal splitters.Of course, ordinary members of the Labour Party will be mightily confused. Many of them still think Labour is committed to a referendum. It still could come to that, of course,May doesnrsquot seize this opportunity.I still harbour vague hopes that A could be revoked, but Irsquom afraid that pro-Europeans are on the wrong side of history right now. The country is destined to leave the EU, because letrsquos face it, Labour under Jeremy Corbyn is and has always been a pro-Brexit party.And after Brexit Day  Well, get ready for Groundhog Day  as negotiations over the future EU trade deal begin all over again.

title: london-based-oil-and-gas-independent-makes-progress-off-scotland
story: Read more: RockRose hails exciting acquisitionRockrose said the production lives of the Ross and Blake fields north east of Aberdeen are being extended from  to at least  in a development that will allow the firm to book around . million barrels oil equivalentadditional reserves.News of the extensions will be studied with interest in the North Sea oil and gas industry amid the official drive to maximise the economic recovery of the UKrsquos oil and gas resources.RockRose has also made progress with plans to bring finds into development.It said yesterday that plans for the development of the Tain field are progressing and are expected to be submitted to the regulator this year. As Tain lies close to Blake it may be possible to link it with production facilities for that field.In October RockRose agreed with Shell to develop the Arran field  miles east of Aberdeen.Read more: Shell provides fresh boost for North Sea oil and gas industryThe firms plans highlight the role that independents such as RockRose are playing in helping to stimulate activity in the North Sea, following the deep downturn triggered by the crude price plunge from .Oil and gas firms slashed spending on North Sea projects amid the resulting pressure on cash. Majors retrenched in the area with some focusing on a narrower range of plum fields or shting investment overseas.Read more: One in three North Sea oil jobs lost since RockRosersquos executive chairman Andrew Austin said: ldquoThe extension of field le at Ross and Blake, supporting the Tain development, further grows the Grouprsquos Preserve base, demonstrating the impact of our continued investment in organic growth.The progress at RockRose has provided vindication for Mr Austinrsquos decision to start the firm in . He felt the downturn that followed the oil price slump created opportunities to build a substantial North Sea business quickly helped by acquisitions.Executives running other independents, including Parkmead Grouprsquos Tom Cross, have noted that assets have been put up for sale at attractive prices in recent years.Read more: Tom Cross eyes North Sea deals as sellers getrealistic amid downturnA former investment banker, Mr Austin has master-minded a number of acquisitions at RockRose that look to have been well-timed.RockRose acquired interests in Ross and Blake and a range of other fields from Japanrsquos Idemitsu in .It acquired a .% interest in Arran from Korean-owned Dana Petroleum for a nominal sum in August.Mr Austin said: ldquoWe remain focussed on continuing to invest in our portfolio to extend field le where possible and to explore options for further value accretive acquisitions.RockRose said the Arran development is progressing to schedule with first gas planned for the first quarter of , allowing it to book .MMboe P reserves.The company expects to be able to fund its share of the development cost from the cashflow generated from its North Sea production.RockRose expects to produce an average of , to , barrels oil equivalent daily in the current year.It had m cash at the start of the year and is debt free.Arran is expected to produce , barrels of oil equivalent daily at peak.The company had .MMboe reserves at January , including some held in fields in the Dutch North Sea and onshore.The group also holds around m barrels oil equivalent contingent C resources, whose commerciality has yet to be confirmed.Shares in RockRose closed up p at p giving the firm a stock market capitalisation of around poundm.In September RockRose said the options for extending the lives of Blake and Ross, which are operated by Repsol Sinopec, included prolonging the le of the existing floating production, storage and offloading vessel used on the fields or replacing it. It did not provide further details yesterday.

title: scottish-economy-faces-major-dislocation-under-no-deal-brexit
story: Dr Gary Gillespie, the chief economic adviser to SNP ministers, said a chaotic exit from Europe would hit logistics, supply chains, trade, investment and market confidence.If the economic shock persisted, it would cause ldquosignicant structural change, he said.In his monthly State of the Economy report, Dr Gillespie laid out a range of data showing Scottish growth was relatively good in , but there were also recent problems.Business confidence had slumped, and warehouse stockpiling had soared, as firms took steps to protect themselves against a breakdown in supplies in the event of a no-deal.Dr Gillespie also issued a new government study showing even Theresa Mayrsquos preferred Brexit plan would hurt the Scottish economy through more red tape and fewer EU workers.It said the impact of non-tarf barriers and ldquomigration shock would be most keenly felt in the chemical and pharmaceutical sector, which could shrink by  per cent.However the biggest impact on the economy overall would be a squeeze on the wholesale and retail sectors, professional and financial services.Exporters of goods would be hit harder than the service sector.In his monthly report, Dr Gillespie highlighted the continued uncertainty caused by the looming date for Brexit and the lack of a settled plan at Westminster.He said: ldquoGiven the proximity to  March deadline, a no-deal Brexit remains a signicantrisk and would lead to a major dislocation to the Scottish economy.ldquoThis would occur through a number of channels - disruptions to logistics, supply, trade, investment, migration and market confidence.ldquoAny shock is likely to have disproportionate sectoral, as well as, regional impacts andprolonged, will lead to signicant structural change in the economy.SNP finance and economy secretary Derek Mackay said it showed the need for the UK government to rule out a no-deal Brexit.He said: ldquoScotlandrsquos economy continues to perform well with further growth and record low unemployment. But we cannot ignore the fact that this is being put at risk by the increasing uncertainty associated with Brexit, and in particular the risk of a no-deal scenario.ldquoBrexit, in whatever form, will cost jobs, make people poorer, damage our society and undermine the democratic decision of the people of Scotland to remain in the EU.Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie said: ldquohe Scottish economy is fragile, with low growth and businesses and consumers worried about the future.ldquoConservative neglect and Labour compliance has taken us to the brink of a no deal Brexit which would devastate the Scottish economy.ldquoItrsquos clearer than ever that we need a Peoplersquos Vote and an exit from Brexit.Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard added: ldquoThis report shows the urgent need for Theresa May to take the threat of a no deal Brexit off the table - but also that our economy needs fundamental change.ldquoLabour will put power, wealth and opportunity back into the hands of people by boosting their wages and giving them more control in our economy."

title: night-time-arts-project-to-be-part-of-hebridean-dark-skies-festival
story: Now the concept behind Whatever Gets You Through The Night, a multi-media artistic reflection of le between the hours of midnight and am, is being adapted for one of the countryrsquos most remote locations seven years after it was first staged.Musicians Emma Pollock and Rachel Sermanni are among the acts performing in a revised version of the project at An Lanntair arts hub in Stornoway on the Western Isles as part of the first Hebridean Dark Skies Festival on Lewis.First conceived by theatre director Cora Bissett and playwright David Greig, Whatever Gets You Through The Night originally featured songs by Pollock and Sermanni with author Alan Bissett and songwriters RM Hubbert, Ricky Ross and Eugene Kelly.Actors Frances Thorburn and John Kielty were joined by aerial artists as an audience, seated on reclaimed seats from Glasgow Corporation buses, were taken on a journey from solitary introspection and cosmic rumination to pounding clubs and the hunt for chips and cheese.The production was accompanied by an album, book and film and won a Creative Scotland Award for Best Theatre in .A long way from Glasgowrsquos Arches, this weekrsquos reduced adaptation is at the heart of the festival programme, augmented by music from Gaelic singer Ceitlin LR Smith and Hebridean songwriter The Sea Atlas, aka Calum Buchanan.Lewis-based festival programmer Andrew Eaton-Lewis, whose band Swimmer One collaborated with Bissett and Greig on the original project, pointed to parallels between what was staged at the Arches and what will be seen in the Western Isles this week.He said: ldquoWhen I was asked to programme the Dark Skies Festival, Emma Pollockrsquos song from the album, Dark Skies, was in my head quite a lot. I really wanted to do something with the song, so we used it in the trailer.ldquoThen after a while I started thinking the same kind of thoughts we had when we were making Whatever Gets You Through The Night, and that it would be a really interesting way to broaden out the festival beyond astronomy and star-gazing. Itrsquos about songs and stories which help you through that time in the night.Mr Eaton-Lewis added: ldquoWhen you come to Lewis people tell you the winters are long and hard because the nights are so long.ldquoBut the long nights can also be magical. A lot of the stories people were coming up with when we were first making that project were about endurance and survival. So it seemed like an interesting thing to explore in this context.The festival, which runs until  February , includes photography exhibitions, film screenings, expert discussion on the cosmos and insight into the inidual benefit of sensory enlightenment through exposure to the dark, with indoor and outdoor venues including the former RAF radar station at Gallan Head, the UKrsquos most north-westerly point.Glasgow-based singer songwriter Emma Pollock said the festivalrsquos appeal lay in its celebration of the winter experience.ldquoItrsquos so dferent to that of the summer on the island or the winter on the mainland, and I think for that reason itrsquos beautul idea, because so many of us just donrsquot get to experience that emptiness or that silence, said the former lead singer of Lanarkshire indie band The Delgados.ldquoThis is essentially a nod to the fact that the contrast between night and day in a rural community is much greater than you ever get living in the city.Ms Pollock will perform her song Dark Skies as part of her performance at An Lanntair, written for the  project as a reflection on growing up in Castle Douglas in Dumfries and Galloway close to the Galloway Forest, one of two Dark Skies Parks in Scotland - the other being in the Cairngorm National Park.She said: ldquoI was thrown back to where I grew up, that emptiness, that rural space which is so much more magnied at night and is such a huge contrast with urban darkness.ldquoIf yoursquore out there and the weather is good, then what you can see is quite incredible. It looks like a traffic jam of stars, you can probably see the Milky Way when the sky is clear enough.ldquoIf yoursquore there long enough and your eyes adjust, yoursquore never going to forget that.Whatever Gets You Through The Night, An Lanntair, Stornoway, Friday. For more info on the Hebridean Dark Skies Festival visit: lanntair darkskies.

title: pmqs-clash-corbyn-brands-mays-brexit-approach-costly-shambolic-and-deliberately-evasive
story: At a boisterous Prime Ministerrsquos Questions, the Labour leader questioned how Mrs May could retain confidence in Chris Grayling, the Transport Secretary, in light of the collapse of the pound. million ferry contract with Seaborne Freight, which was supposed to provide additional cross-Channel services to ease disruption in the case of a no-deal withdrawal from the EU.The PM explained how the Government had let three contracts  per cent of which was let to DFDS and Brittany Ferries.ldquoDue diligence was carried out on all of these contracts, she declared, stressing how the Government would ensure the transport capacity was there in the event of a no-deal outcome.But Mr Corbyn called on Mrs May to correct the record, pointing out how Mr Grayling told MPs the decision to award the contract to Seaborne Freight had no cost to the taxpayer when the National Audit Office, the money watchdog, found pound, had been spent on external consultants to assess the bid.The PM again stressed ldquoproper due diligence had been carried out when the contracts were let, which included third-party assessment of the companies bidding for the contracts.The Labour leader told Mrs May he was really impressed by how she could keep a straight face while insisting due diligence had been carried out.He explained how external advisers had described the contract with Seaborne Freight, a start-up company, as ldquohigh-risk. Why, asked Mr Corbyn, in the circumstances did Mr Grayling proceed with the contract The Labour leader said the advisers were instructed to restrict their due diligence to the ldquoface value of the presentation made by Seaborne Freight, a company with no trading history and that a Freedom of Information request showed the Transport Secretary had ldquobypassed normal procurement rules because a  of experts was denied scrutiny of the deal.But the PM hit back, pointing out how the contract was awarded ldquofollowing commercial, technical and financial assurance at a level in line with the companyrsquos status as a new entrant to the market, carried out not only by senior department officials but also by experienced third-party organisations.She also made clear ldquono money was paid out to Seaborne Freight.However, the Labour leader said the Transport Secretary had ignored warnings about drones regarding airport security, had given a pound. billion contract to Carillion despite warnings about their finances and had overseen the disastrous new rail timetable last year.ldquoHow on earth can the Prime Minister say she has confidence in the Transport Secretary  asked Mr Corbyn.Mrs May insisted Mr Grayling was delivering the biggest rail investment programme since the Victorian era, spending nearly poundbn on improving the railways to deliver better journeys  per cent higher on average every year than under a Labour Government.She then attacked the Labour leaderrsquos own approach to Brexit, saying voters still did not knowbacked a second referendum, a deal or even Brexit.The PM added: ldquoHe prefers ambiguity and playing politics to acting in the national interest. People used to say he was a conviction politician not anymore.

title: brexit-nicola-sturgeon-announces-no-deal-information-campaigns
story: Appearing on ITVrsquos Peston programme later tonight, the First Minister in a pre-recorded interview spoke out following a meeting of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Resilience Committee.Noting how the body was more used to dealing with bad weather or the impact of terrorist attacks, she said: ldquoWersquove been focusing today on how we cope with the implications of no-deal and, frankly, that discussion is deeply depressing and very frustrating because itrsquos not inevitable and we shouldnrsquot have to be doing it.ldquoTo be sitting in peacetime in a prosperous country talking about the possibility of food shortages and medicine shortages is frankly incredible, declared Ms Sturgeon.She went on: ldquoItrsquos not inevitable. The Government at UK level should take that prospect off the table, it should rule out no-deal and its failure to do so with every day that passes right now becomes increasingly reckless and negligent.But, she explained, such a prospect did put a responsibility on the Scottish Government to increase its planning.ldquoWe stepped up the level of our planning today, the FM revealed.ldquoWe canrsquot mitigate all impacts of that, the impacts will be so wide-ranging and so severe that it will not be possible to take away all of that impact but itrsquos important that within our areas of responsibility wersquore doing everything that we possibly can and wersquore very focused on exactly that.Asked what advice she would be giving to Scottish householders, Ms Sturgeon replied: ldquoThe Scottish Government over the next few weeks will run public information campaigns.ldquoWersquoll look to give not just advice to households but we will give advice, we already give advice to businesses and to all sectors of the economy.ldquoOf course therersquos a balance we need to strike. We donrsquot want to unnecessarily worry and scare people but with every day that passes itrsquos more important that the implications are understood and that the Scottish Government working with our partners, local government, the business community and others, that we take all possible steps.When it was put to her that Theresa May did not have the power to take no-deal off the table and she might have to ask the EU for an extension to the Article  process, which they could refuse, the SNP leader replied: ldquoOkay, I accept that point but she should request it and the SNP amendment that will be tabled for tomorrow makes that call on the UK Government to request an extension.ldquoIt is based on what I hear from Europe. It is unlikely that that would be turned down by the European Union of course, it is more likely to be acceptedthat request comes with a clear plan to take a dferent approach.ldquoItrsquos not going to help in the medium to long terman extension is simply to continue this unseemly argument that the House of Commons is engaged in right now because they canrsquot agree what they want to do, she added.

title: theresa-may-faces-valentines-day-commons-humiliation-as-tory-brexiteers-poised-to-defeat-government-motion
story: Such a move would further hamper the Prime Ministerrsquos efforts to get the EU to agree a revised deal as the clock runs down to exit day on March .As MPs prepared for the latest Commons showdown, Nicola Sturgeon hit out at the ldquofrankly incredible consequences of a no-deal outcome, including shortages of food and medicine.In an interview with ITVrsquos Peston programme, following a meeting of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Resilience Committee, the First Minister insisted a no-deal Brexit was not inevitable.ldquoThe Government at UK level should take that prospect off the table, it should rule out no-deal and its failure to do so with every day that passes right now becomes increasingly reckless and negligent, she declared.In the second next-steps Commons debate and vote today, the Government has put forward a seemingly innocuous motion, reiterating Parliamentrsquos support for the ldquoapproach to leaving the EU expressed by this House on January .:Brexit: Theresa May accused of showing contempt for democracyLast monthrsquos votes not only saw an amendment passed that called for the backstop to be replaced by ldquoalternative arrangements, which the Government championed, but also one rejecting the UK leaving the EU without a deal.On Tuesday night, Olly Robbins, the UKrsquos chief Brexit official, was reportedly overheard in a Brussels bar, saying Mrs Mayrsquos strategy was to offer a last-minute Commons vote in March for either her revised deal or a y delay to Brexit.During PMQs, she brushed aside the claim, saying people should not rely ldquoon what someone said to someone  as overheard by someone  in a bar, again emphasising the Article  timescale ran out on March .No  sought to disabuse people of the notion Mrs May was surreptitiously ruling out a no-deal outcome.Her spokesman declared: ldquoIf yoursquore asking me a question: does no-deal remain on the table  The answer is yes.But members of the Conservativesrsquo anti-EU European Research Council made clear they could not support the ldquoclumsily-worded Government motion.Mark Francois, its vice-chairman, said: ldquoWe cannot vote for this as it is currently configured because it rules out no-deal and removes our negotiating leverage in BrusselshellipIt is madness.Several amendments have been tabled. John Bercow, the Speaker, will decide which ones will be debated and voted on this evening.Labour has tabled a proposal, which would require the Government to either put its deal to a vote by February  or allow Parliament to take control of the process.Its Shadow Brexit Secretary, Keir Starmer - who on Wednesday had "frank and serious" talks with David Lidington, the PMrsquos de facto deputy - said Labour was committed to preventing Mrs May from pursuing a "reckless" policy of running down the clock so MPs were faced with a choice between her deal or no-deal with just days to go to exit day.The SNP tabled an amendment requiring the UK Government to begin immediate negotiations with the European Council to extend Article  by no less than three months.:Ian Blackford accuses Theresa May of rewriting the history books over BrexitIan Blackford, the party leader at Westminster, said: ldquoThe UK Government must stop running down the clock and put the brakes on Brexit before we are dragged off the clf-edge with catastrophic damage to jobs, living standards and the economy.Other amendments include one tabled by Ken Clarke, the former Tory Chancellor, calling for votes on ious Brexit options and one from the SNPrsquos Angus MacNeil to scrap the Article  process altogether.While todayrsquos vote will be an important indicator of Parliamentrsquos mood, any successful amendment will not be legally binding on the Government.In contrast, a promised next-steps vote on February  is being described as ldquoHigh Noon as it is when a new amendment, drawn up by Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper, will be tabled, stipulatingthere were no deal by mid-March, MPs would either vote to agree a no-deal Brexit or to require the PM to seek an extension of Article .A similar move was defeated in January but the new version appears to be gaining more support and could even be backed by Cabinet ministers, who would resign to do so. One Whitehall insider said: ldquoIt looks like it could get through this time.

title: wouldnt-you-love-to-see-the-end-of-st-valentines-day
story: Herersquos how it runs yoursquove woken up to a Hallmark card from which you can almost smell the cheesethen later tonight you and your partner will be squeezed into a tiny corner table at a restaurant where you will eat a very average dinner while all the time wishing Richard Curtis had supplied you with a script. You see, while love is indeed a many splendoured thing, it can dry up, unlike the labradoodle puppyrsquos pee in the hall, so often your default discussion piece these days.Thankfully, the closeness of the couple at the next table is such you can distract yourself with their delightfully inane conversation thatrsquos as surreal as a Bros twinsrsquo argument ndash which makes your own puppy talk seem almost Stephen Fry-clever by comparison. But the distraction doesnrsquot last. Before you know it yoursquore stupid enough to check your smart phone a dozen times. Instead of staring into limpid eyes yoursquore looking at someone looking at you as though yoursquore a flatmate whorsquos late with the rent. What a brilliant wake-up call!Yet, herersquos what pushes your coupling wonderfully over the edge. You check into the city centre hotel for the night, order a bottle of fizz and later discover the night cost as much as thebill for Derek Mackayrsquos public speaking lessons. Now yoursquore one of the m Brits out there who celebrate VD ndash but wonderitrsquos really worth it  Yoursquore both thinking:love is blind whatrsquos the point of this expensive lingerie Tomorrow, reality will dawn. The relationship may still have its Hepburn-Tracy trace elements but theyrsquore fading like sun-exposed celluloid. The previous night had revealed a huge gap between expectations and reality. This is a relationship screaming out for Relate ndash or a orce lawyer ndash who will delight in the new business. Everybody wins!Read more: Valentinersquos Day: Scotlandrsquos  most romantic spotsYet, itrsquos not just long-term partners who can learn from the special day. The construct is intensely valuable for youngsters. Just as the end of a goldfishrsquos le teaches little people about death, VD slaps the tiny face with the realisation love is often unrequited. Itrsquos all very well Albert Camus claiming ldquoI know of only one duty, and that is to love but whatthe boy girl in P thinks yoursquore as appealing as broccoli Yet, should we be surprised Valentinersquos Day so often signals disaster ahead  Depending on research, the occasion emerged either from a bizarre Roman fertility ceremony, whereby men would sacrice dogs and goats, skin them, then whip women with the hides . Or, much later, Emperor Claudius II had two men named Valentine executed on February , who became martyrs.Perhaps the celebration could be based on young Valentinus. Awaiting death for his Christian beliefs, he wrote a love note to a jailerrsquos blind daughter, signed ldquoFrom your Valentine.Whichever, itrsquos clear each involved humiliation ndash and worse. Thankfully, this theme has continued. Valentinersquos Day is either a terric reminder yoursquore not in a relationship, that you used to bein a relationship, or yoursquorein a relationship and perhaps shouldnrsquot be.Yes, some will say they recall the thrill of receiving the unsigned, curious card. But try that at work today and HR could well be talking to you about sexual harassment.Read more: The Great Escape isnrsquot a film, itrsquos a lesson in survivalNow, you may be thinking this to be a rather dark take on the most romantic day, emerging from the mind of a desperate singleton just a click away from ordering up an Eastern European internet bride. Well, that day may indeed be close. However, who can deny therersquos too much of the Steve Wright Sunday-Morning-Love -Songs smugness around  Does Steve factor in those confined to an MS dinner for one American psychologist Melissa Orlov writes: ldquoThere are probably couples out there that think Valentinersquos is a great holiday. But I donrsquot see them in my marriage consulting practice. Instead, right around February  I inevitably start fielding calls about hopelessness and disappointment. In recent times, one crisis call centre in the United States reported a  per cent rise in helpline calls on Love Day.But donrsquot think Irsquom a Byron-hating, heartless killjoy. Irsquove watched Four Weddings at least five times, I love anything by Nora Ephron, Some Like It Hot, Breakfast At Tfanyrsquos and Roman Holiday .Teary teenage eyes were swtly, secretly wiped at when Love Story cancered out Ali McGraw and when Dr Zhivago gave Omar Shar a heart attack as he jumped off the tram in pursuit of Julie Christie.My favourite record is Eltonrsquos Your Song. The reality is Irsquom right with Shelley when he wrote: ldquoNothing in the world is single. All things by a law ine. In one spirit meet and mingle.But Valentinersquos Day  Celebrate ityou can, butyou have to declare undying love then do it quietly. Preferably in October.

title: model-of-maid-of-the-loch-unveiled-in-its-new-home
story: A hand-made replica of the Maid of the Loch paddle-steamer, painstakingly fashioned by Lachie Stewart, a lelong model-maker, was unveiled at its new home, in a gleaming new display case at the Loch Lomond Shores mall.The : large-scale has been moved from the paddle steamer itself, and is said to provide a true likeness from when the Maid was in commission. Its decks are crowded with small figures representing passengers.Mr Stewart said: ldquoI believe the scale of the ship works very well - it is large enough to add the small figures and they really make the Maid come alive. I hope seeing it encourages viewers to make a donation and help this wonderful vessel to sail again on the waters of Loch Lomond.John Beveridge, Director of the Loch Lomond Steamship Company, said yesterday: ldquoThe generous gt donated by Lachie has grabbed the attention of many of our visitors, both old and young, through its incredible detail and large-scale size.ldquoWersquore now sharing its charming features with our close neighbours at Loch Lomond Shores, to show what a typical day of sailing onboard Maid of the Loch would be like. We hope this inspires visitors to the Shores to climb onboard the cause and envision the Maid as a sailing paddle steamer once again for the enjoyment of everyone, today and for future generations.The Maid currently operates as a static tourist attraction and hopes to gain industrial museum status for the ship and steam slipway as a growing number of artefacts are collected and restored to working order.The paddle steamer will reopen in Easter for open season with the Balloch Steam Slipways ldquoIn Steam at the weekends. This will show the steam engine and gearing system in operation, with audio-visuals describing how the slipway pulls the Maid out of the water.A pound, capital grant funding award by the Scottish Government to the Maid of the Loch was confirmed last December, meaning that the goal of ing the ship to sail lives on.

title: winner-of-the-wildlife-photo-of-the-year-revealed
story: The tender and unusual moment was captured byLondon photographer David Lloyd who spotted the catsmdash brothers, most likely mdash in Tanzania in March  and trained his camera.The resulting image, "Bond of Brothers," won the Wildle Photographer of the YearLUMIX Peoples Choice Award from Londons Natural History Museum.Speaking to USA Today, Lloyd said that he has always been drawnto the perceptive nature of animals that often goes overlooked.:- A year in photographs"The greet lasted a lot longer than the usual three or five seconds, it was almost half a minute of nuzzle and gentle head butt," he said."There was no doubt the high level of emotion, feeling, respect and dependability between these two for each other."The photograph won out of  images compiled by the Natural History Museum as part of its  competition, which received , submissions."Lions are iniduals with complex social bonds, and Davidrsquos winning picture provides a glimpse into their inner world," Michael Dixon, the museums director, said in a statement.:Stacyrsquos wildle image is picture perfectThe Wildle Photographer of the Years peoples choice award honors outstanding nature photography as decided by the public.Last years winner featuredagorilla saved from a bushmeat market, resting drowsily in the arms of the man who helped rescue her.

title: north-and-south-uist-try-to-cash-in-on-tourist-boom
story: Now a major campaign is being launched ndash with marketing even on the streets of Manchester ndash to make visitors more aware of the charm and beauty of the sparsely populated Uists in the Outer Hebrides, which are often overlooked by tourists.:People used to think they had to get off the island, now they see Uist as a place they donrsquot have to leaveNorth Uist and South Uist are linked by causeways running via Benbecula and Grimsay, and the entire group is known as the Uists. Among them the islands have less than , residents, but they are home to Europersquos biggest missile test range, incredible historic sites and remarkable wildle such as golden eagles, wading birds and otters.Flora MacDonald, who helped Bonnie Prince Charlie escape after Culloden, was born in Milton in South Uist and the island is home to a nature reserve and a number of sites ofarchaeological interest, including the only location in the UK where prehistoric mummies have been found.Now CalMac Ferries is set to launch a new national marketing campaign ahead of the tourism season, designed toraise awareness of Uist as an ldquounmissable getaway.:Uist is becoming a magnet for young people who are flocking for peace, tranquility... and poor internet connectivityAndrew MacNair, head of marketing at Calmac Ferries, said: ldquoThe Outer Hebrides are becoming one of the most talked about tourism destinations the world over, and The lsquoSea Uist Soon campaign has been created to ensure a successful tourism season in .ldquoAfter operational issues endured last season, we wanted to continue to support the region not only with our services, but by working alongside the localtourism industry to promote all thatrsquos great about Uist.

title: scottish-government-to-overhaul-hr-operation-after-alex-salmond-case
story: SNP ministers are spending an initial pound, hiring consultants to help draw up a ldquoproposed HR Transformation Strategy for their troubled People Directorate.Edinburgh-based PA Consulting Group will now work on an analysis of options, targets, a ldquotransformation roadmap, an outline business case and a detailed business case.:Business diary of Nicola Sturgeons top aide records gym class but not Alex Salmond meetingThe work also covers ldquoHR best practice, suggesting shortcomings in the current set-up need to be addressed.The contract ndash awarded without being publicly advertised under an expedited system ndash comes just a month after the failure in Mr Salmondrsquos case.The former First Minister won a judicial review hearing at the Court of Session over the handling of the governmentrsquos investigation into alleged sexual misconduct complaints.:Calls for public inquiry into "unlawful" handling of sexual misconduct complaints against Alex SalmondMinisters admitted the probe was unfair, unlawful and tainted by apparent bias when it emerged the chief investigator had prior contact with the two complainers, which rendered the process invalid and left taxpayers with a pound, legal bill.The probe was conducted by the People Directorate which is now at the heart of the ldquotransformation.The government confirmed under Freedom of Information this week that investigator Judith Mackinnon had been appointed by Director of People Nicola Richards.In an email to Ms Mackinnon last January, Ms Richards said: ldquoI have received this formal complaint from [redacted] and I am appointing you as the senior investigating officer. Would you be able to review this and get the investigation underway "I have thanked [redacted] and said that you will be in touch. Ms Mackinnon did not recuse herself.Separately, Mr Salmond last month appeared in court charged with two counts of attempted rape, nine of sexual assault, two of indecent assault and one of breach of the peace.He strongly denies any criminality.According to a government contract notice, ministers want their HR consultants to work with the People Directorate Improvement Programme team to ldquotest their vision.PA Consulting and the governmentrsquos HR bosses will look at ldquoHR services trends, and the lsquoart-of-the possiblersquo... emerging technologiesand HR lsquobest-practicersquo.In the contract notice, the governmentrsquos People Directorate said: ldquoOur aim is to become a lsquofit-for-purpose, modern, continuously improving HRthat makes the most of our people, processes and technology."Our services will offer an improved employee experience and will be value-for-money.rsquo We are seeking to appoint a Supplier who will work collaboratively with us to develop a strategy that will enable us to deliver services in the most optimal, economical and efficient way.The contract was not openly advertised, but awarded through the Quick Quote system meant for relatively minor contracts, where potential suppliers are approached directly.There were five bidders for the work, with the winning bid pound,.PA Consulting is now due to start the preliminary ldquodiscovery phase next Monday and finish by May .A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoWe operate a shared HR service for a number of government agencies."We are transforming the service to meet the needs of the customer base and to ensure the efficiency of our processes and technology.

title: how-can-the-clyde-heat-your-home-your-office-or-our-public-buildings
story: But appearances can, and do, deceive. The river on which Glasgow built its history and its industry is about to serve the cityrsquos population once again, this time as a source of renewable heat energy. Under an ambitious development plan, the new Queenrsquos Quay regeneration project in Clydebank will see the installation of MW of water source heat pumps. These will extract warmth from the riverand convert it to energy to supply the pound million complex.This energy project, costing pound million to implement, will heat homes, businesses and some public buildings, including Clydebank Town Hall along with the library, leisure centre and West College Scotland.At its centre is a dedicated energy centre connected to . kilometres of district heating pipe networking the properties. Work on building this is now well underway and initial connections to some of the buildings within the plan are set to go live later this year.The technology works by extracting heat from the water in a similar way to the technique used by a refrigerator to cool its contents. It has existed since the s, works well in the UK climate and can provide heating during the winter, even at temperatures of minus  degrees.The district heating network project, on the site of the former John Brown Shipyard, is being delivered by Vital Energi, a sustainable energy company based in Blackburn, Lancashire. According to Scott Lutton, its Operations Manager, it is by far the largest project of its type to date in the UK.Regeneration plans for John Brown shipyardldquoWe expect we will be connecting buildings to the energy centre over the next five to  years, he adds. ldquoIt is going to be iconic and visually attractive, with illumination and even a promenade walkway. This is a very exciting moment in the history of Scotlandrsquos energy infrastructure. Water source heat pumps are a low-carbon technology which will become more effective in reducing emissions as the grid decarbonises.ldquoWe hope that, when complete, it will prove an inspiration to other local authorities wanting to reduce their carbon emissions.The Queens Quay site is owned by Clydeside Regeneration Limitedwith West Dunbartonshire Councilproviding infrastructure funding. Dawn Developments Ltd is responsible for development management on behalf of CRL.West Dunbartonshire Council is equally enthusiastic about the initiative. Councillor Iain McLaren, its Convener of Infrastructure, Regeneration and Economic Development, says: ldquoThe district heating network will have a hugely positive impact on Queens Quay and Clydebank as a whole.The new Queenrsquos Quay regeneration project in Clydebank, will soon be hooked up to the River Clyde by . kilometres of district heating pipe acting as a natural source of energyAnother heat pump energy development could also help to cement Glasgowrsquos reputation as a pioneer when it comes to the roll-out of heat pump energy projects.The scheme, in the Gorbals, would again draw energy from the Clyde and heat to connected buildings, delivering signicant carbon reduction and making a further contribution to climate change goals. It is, however, currently on hold because of delays in public funding.River-based heat pump schemes have to combine a number of dferent disciplines alongside engineering, such as ecology, the natural environment and, in the case of Glasgowrsquos main waterway, a unique and historic heritage.ldquoThe Clyde is hugely symbolic and signicant to Glasgow, says Philip Macdonald of Oberlanders Architects, which has an interest in the technology in the city. ldquoTherersquos a definite desire to make sure we do the right thing.But the river is only one potential source of renewable heat for the cityrsquos population. Equally promising ndashperhaps even more unlikely ndash is its network of underground mineshafts and tunnels, long abandoned and now filled with huge amounts of water.Glasgow City Council is working with the British Geological Survey in looking at the possibilities of employing heat pump technology here too. It would help the city to meet government targets ensuring that  per cent of heat demand comes from renewable sources by .Modelling work has been carried out and in theory, it is possible that nearly half of the local demand for heat could be catered for in this way.This would confirm the area as a European leader in green energy innovation as well as major contribution to a low carbon environment.Glasgowrsquos proud industrial heritage of coal and river may now be firmly in the past. But itrsquos wonderfully fitting that it is being imaginatively reinvented to serve it ndash and the planet - well into the future.The Heraldrsquos Climate for Change initiative supports efforts being made by the ScottishGovernmentwith key organisations and campaign partners. title: key-sturgeon-adviser-urges-softest-possible-form-of-scottish-independence
story: Andrew Wilson, who chaired the SNPrsquos Growth Commission, also likened leaving the UK to a ldquoprocess rather than an event and said Scotland was on a ldquojourney without end.He said: ldquoIn the parlance of Brexit, we offer the softest of possible changes to the current arrangements, not the hardest. We recognise the level of integration and all the ties that have bound us for centuries. We create a  that can uny a majority for progress that stands a chance of winning and winning big.And he mocked Yes campaigners who saw independence as an abrupt radical change.ldquoSomewould rather move immediately and overnight to a Marxist revolutionary state. That is their right, but they wonrsquot win the chance to try, he said.:Former SNP MPs Indyref Tube plan branded unhingedThe comments will infuriate many within the wider Yes movement and reinforce the impression of the SNP hierarchy deliberating deflating expectations over Indyref.SNP MP Angus Macneil, former MP George Kerevan and former SNP leader Alex Salmond have all argued using the chaos over Brexit to press for a second referendum.But in an America TV interview last week, Ms Sturgeon said it was too soon for voters to come to an ldquoinformed decision and ldquocalm consideration was required instead.:Nicola Sturgeon: too soon to make informed decision on independenceMr Wilson, a former MSP who is now a corporate lobbyist, last year produced the SNPrsquos updated economic blueprint for an independent Scotland.It argued for a decade of restrained public spending after a Yes vote in order to halve Scotlandrsquos deficit, and the unofficial use of sterling instead of a new Scottish currency.His Growth Commission is now being chewed over by the SNP members.Writing in The National, Mr Wilson said Brexit meant there had been a fundamental change in circumstances since , and the last White Paper on independence.Brexit had also shown how long and dficult constitutional change could be.:SNP MP warns against bouncing country into IndyrefHe wrote: ldquoThe reality is that all change of such signicance in any organisation, let alone a major country, is a process rather than an event.ldquoTransitions take time as issues are worked through, new institutions built, agreements struck, and strategies put into place and then into action.ldquoA new Scottish White Paper will require to learn many lessons from , what has happened since and what is going so comprehensively wrong with Brexit.ldquoThe report of the Sustainable Growth Commission was designed to answer a brief to think through all of these points. It does not shirk the dficult questions and seeks to provide a sound framework and straight and honest answers. In doing so it seeks a prospectus that can uny a settled will behind Scotlandrsquos next step along our lsquojourney without endrsquo.:Alex Salmond takes swipe at SNP leadership over IndyrefMr Wilson said ldquoall of would love Rome to be built in a day, but the lesson of Brexit was that ldquohonesty, candour and realistic vision was the most likely to succeed.On currency, he said an independent Scotland would start bny keeping the pound, and only move to its own currency and Central Banksix key economic tests were passed.ldquoThis question could be re-examined every year in a report to Parliament, he said.In simple terms, passing the tests means it will be in the interests of our economy, trade, government and public finances and therefore services, citizens, jobs and employers to create a new Scottish currency.Tory MSP Adam Tomkins said:"The Nationalists are desperate for independence and they will do or say anything to get it.First their ill-fated White Paper was rejected by the people in the  referendum.ldquoThen Mr Wilsonrsquos growth commission blueprint for an austerity independence was rejected by his own SNP.Now theyrsquore onto their third attempt to woo voters by pretending that independence is not really independence at all.ldquoHospitals are in crisis, teachers are contemplating unprecedented strike action and roads are crumbling - the SNP has many more pressing matters to be focusing on than independence, whatever it is that means this week.Labour MSPJames Kelly added:"The author of the so-called Growth Commission can try and rebrand leaving the UK however he likes, but in reality his plans mean another decade of austerity for Scotland and an economic model that works for bigbusiness, not workers."Pamela Nash, chief executive of the pro-UK Scotland in Uniongroup, said:ldquoThere is no such thing as soft independence.ldquoIndependence would involve breaking up the most successful union the world has ever seen, building barriers between families, friends and neighbours.ldquoIt would ide our home market, jeopardising our economy, and lead to further and deeper austerity.ldquoWith the SNPrsquos proposal to rejoin the EU, an independent Scotland would have to sign up to the euro and there is the very real possibility of a hard border with the rest of the UK.ldquoVoters wonrsquot be fooled by this ndash the majority of people in Scotland know we are better off together and want Scotland to remain part of the UK, building a shared future based on economic prosperity.Separately, SNP ministers have been criticised for repeatedly refusing to say whether they have taken legal advice on holding a wildcat Catalan-style referendum on independence.The Scottish LibDems accused the government of ldquostonewalling on the issue after the top law officer refused to say whether he had been consulted on the matter.Responding to a request for details from MSP Mike Rumbles, the Lord Advocate James Wolffe QC said ldquoconvention meant it was inappropriate for him to comment.ldquoIt is however open to you to ask the Scottish Government what its position is, he said.But Mr Rumbles said he had already been given the brush-off by ministers.Theresa May has refused to grant Holyrood a so-called Section  order empowering it to hold another legally watertight referendum, leading to speculation about a wildcat vote, such as the one held in Catalonia in defiance of the Spanish government.Ms Sturgeon has also always said a Section  referendum, of the kind held in , is the gold standard, and has show no appetite for a Catalan-style vote.However Mr Rumbles said: ldquoThe Scottish Government are going to outrageous s to avoid telling the public what they are plotting behind closed doors. Ministers just shuffle excuses back and forward between themselves. Itrsquos not good enough.ldquoPeople have a right to know what their government is up to. Rather than stonewalling, government ministers mustto Parliament to confirm whether they are actively considering a wildcat independence referendum without a section  order.

title: do-you-agree-with-the-proposed-parking-levy
story: It is a clear indication that we need to address attitudes towards active travel and air quality and normalise the prioritisation of sustainable transport.News of the governmentrsquos deal has sparked a backlash from politicians, lobby groups and certain elements of the business sector, undoubtedly stoked by a media seemingly keen to appeal to car owners rather than those reading their coverage on a bus or train.The Workplace Parking Levy would essentially charge employers who provide parking spaces for their staff. Such a scheme has operated in Nottingham since  and has raised over pound million for sustainable transport projects.The idea of a WPL in Scotland is not new. It has been the subject of debate in both Glasgow and Edinburgh councils and the introduction of WPL enabling legislation has been backed by COSLA.In fact, so widespread is the support for a WPL it would most likely have been included within the current TransportBill by amendment regardless of the Scottish Greens budget bargain.It is a demonstrably successful model that was progressing towards inclusion in forthcoming legislation.Why the uproar  Put simply, for too many people car remains king.Paul White is deputy director of CPT ScotlandI am reminded of the annual indignation that accompanies the publication of the fines raised by bus lane infringements in Glasgow and Edinburgh. Press reports have branded the bus lanes lsquonotoriousrsquo and the fines lsquoruthlessrsquo. What other parking or driving restriction is treated in this manner  When a local authority introduces a bus priority measure, or a bike lane, or even a WPL, it is implementing a policy action fully in line with the transport hierarchy that lies at the heart of our national, regional and local transport strategies.Sustainable and active transport ndash walking, cycling and bus - should be prioritised.The Workplace Parking Levy is attracting such a negative response in part because it is an outlier, a scheme that dares to introduce an element of road-use charging. A rare lsquostickrsquo to encourage more sustainable travel choices.If government is to meet its climate change goals then brave decisions are required. It is by challenging the dominance of the car that we canlead attitudinal change.The Heraldrsquos Climate for Change initiative supports efforts being made by the ScottishGovernmentwith key organisations and campaign partners. title: royal-bank-rugbyforce-returns-to-attract-new-members-to-local-clubs
story: Now in its eleventh year, the nationwide rugby programme supports clubs by providing funding to help them attract new members, make improvements to facilities and to help clubs become more sustainable for the future.Three out of every four clubs in Scotland have benefited from Royal Bank RugbyForce support since  and the call is going out for more to apply and enjoy its support.At the home of Scottish rugby at BT Murrayfield, Menrsquos and Womenrsquos internationalists Grant Gilchrist, Megan Kennedy, Fraser Brown, Lana Skeldon and Jamie Ritchie, urged clubs up and down the country to think how they could benefit and become lsquoLoudest and Proudestrsquo for Scotland.Over  years, more than half a million pounds has been distributed amongst Scottish clubs and this yearrsquos campaign will see a celebration of the grassroots game with the Royal Bank RugbyForce weekend taking place on - August, where rugby clubs will host events for the local community and put their funding to use as they prepare their club for the new season.This yearrsquos #loudestandproudest theme comes as Royal Bank of Scotland encourages the whole of Scotland to join the rugby community and cheer on the national side. With the Guinness Six Nations underway and the Rugby World Cup on the horizon,  is set to be a thrilling year for Scottish Rugby.At BT Murrayfield, the Scotland internationalists met youth players Poppy Mellanbyand Ruari Watsonfrom Biggar RFC in South Lanarkshire and Evie Blairand Fraser Hayfrom Lasswade RFC in Midlothian.The potential rugby stars of tomorrow swapped the rugby ball for the microphone and put the international players through their paces with a series of one to one interviews, tackling them on subjects such as ldquowho is the loudest in the Scotland squad  and ldquowhat do you eat for breakfast .This yearrsquos  winning clubs will be awarded the ldquoloudest and proudest package which will see them receive pound, as well as a visit by one of the Scottish gamersquos biggest personalities on Royal Bank RugbyForce weekend. The chosen clubs will also receive full event support from Royal Bank of Scotland as they create a truly memorable day which places rugby at the heart of the community.Eight other lsquoStarrsquo clubs will receive pound, funding as well as rugby kit and appearances from Scotland rugby personalities who will be on hand during the weekend to roll up their sleeves and get involved with everything from coaching and development to DIY.An additional eight lsquoChampionrsquo clubs will secure pound, of financial support, with all other participating clubs in with the chance of receiving pound. All qualying clubs will receive digital support packs to host their own Royal Bank RugbyForce Weekend.Scotland international and former Alloa RFC player Grant Gilchrist is one of the elite stars supporting the campaign this year and features in a series of short films encouraging clubs across Scotland to sign up to Royal Bank RugbyForce in .Grant said: ldquoSo many professional players take their first steps on a rugby field at a grassroots club. Without the tireless efforts of community clubs across Scotland, we wouldnrsquot have the talent and love for the game that we have today.ldquoSupporting your local team is so important. Royal Bank RugbyForce is an excellent initiative and itrsquos great to see so many local clubs in Scotland receiving the support they need to develop the next generation of Scottish rugby talent.Malcolm Buchanan, chairman, Royal Bank of Scotland, Scotland Board, said: ldquoWersquore very proud of our continued commitment to rugby in Scotland. The passion for the game remains strong and wersquore delighted to be able to play a part in supporting local rugby communities across the country with both financial and practical assistance.ldquoOur application process is designed with ease in mind and we would encourage clubs across the country to apply for this yearrsquos grants.  is set to be an important year for Scottish rugby and we want to help make sure that our grassroots clubs across the country can benefit too.Keith Wallace, Club President at Haddington RFC, one of the top two winning clubs in  said: ldquoRoyal Bank RugbyForce weekend was a fantastic occasion for our club as we took on the world record for the most players ever to take part in a game of touch rugby. With  players, aged from five to seventy-four, getting on the pitch, wersquore confident as we await ratication that we successfully kicked the previous record of  into touch.ldquoAside from the Guinness World Record attempt, we also used the grant money to contribute towards a recruitment drive to increase playing numbers at all levels and funding community engagement projects.ldquoWe would like to thank the Royal Bank of Scotland without whose support the event would not have been possible, in particular their many staff and advisors who helped massively on the day.

story: A. title: virtual subsea work for meldrum pupils
story: Meldrum Academy pupils have taken part in OPITO#s Energise Your Futureevent.The academy was one of eight north east schools to have taken part in the initiative that was held during the final day of Subsea Expo at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre on Thursday, February .EYF is managed by OPITO, the global, not-for-profit, skills body for the energy industry.The event aims to inspire and encourage more young people in the UK to consider the industry as a career choice by providing a chance to get up close with key companies and people who can help explain their businesses as well as roles and routes into the sector.This year,  companies were involved in the Subsea Expo programme.Marine engineering firm EC-OG offered pupils the chance to use its latest virtual reality technology which will transport them subsea to inspect its subsea power hub and battery equipment.John McDonald, OPITO CEO, said: “As more and more oil and gas companies embrace new techniques such as virtual reality and articial intelligence, it is important that young people see and hear first-hand what the future of the industry looks like and the vast and exciting opportunities these developments present to them.”Attracting young talent remains a key focus for the sector.The recent OPITO UKCS Workforce Dynamics Review showed thatthe sector achieves its ambitions set out in Vision ,, people will need to be recruited over the next two decades.Around , of those are expected to be in roles that don’t yet exist.Mr McDonald added: “We are currently developing a new UKCS Skills Strategy to support the skills that will be required by both new and existing personnel operating in the North Sea into the next decade.“It is important we provide opportunities through initiatives like EYF to help young people discover that this is a sector with a future worth considering that also has the learning infrastructure in place to help develop their career and unlock their potential.”The pupils taking part were all aged between  to . title: farmers invited to getting greener grass event
story: Soil Association Scotland is inviting farmers to a free event with pasture expert Andre van Barneveld to find out how to prepare for the grazing season ahead.Feed stocks may be low due to the extreme weather conditions last year, but are there any management options that could help maximise spring pasture production Andre van Barneveld of Graise Consultancy says that although there is no silver bullet, there are things you can do to make the most of your pasture.“My approach revolves around rotational grazing,” he says.“Grazing stimulates grass growth, butyou have all the stock on all the grass all of the time it doesn’t work – the grass needs time to recover.”He says nitrogen fertiliser can be used in a minimal way to reduce costs as well as environmental impact.“There’s no point putting it on before grazing as nitrogen can’t stimulate grass growththere’s no growth there – you’d be wasting your money.”And there is attention to be paid long term to soil health.“Rotational grazing is better for soils in the long term because it improves root structure, which gives you better grass. It’s all linked in.“It’s about truly understanding the value of grass. If you value it, and you manage it through the season it can have a real impact on profitability.”Knowledge Transfer Specialist at QMS, Emily Grant, said: “Spring grass is hugely valuable to any livestock system, whether for lambing ewes, calving cows or growing youngstock. Making the most of it will help to not only keep feed and housing costs in check, but also set up high quality pastures for the rest of the grazing season.”The event will be held on Tuesday, February  atThainstone Agricultural Centre, Inverurie from –pm.It is free to farmers and land managers but booking is required.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"MasterChef stars John Torode and Spencer Matthews will attend this years Taste of Grampian"  MasterChef stars for Taste of Grampian viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"To book visit www.soilassociation.org, call Lyn on   or email lwhite@soilassociation.org.Come along and find how you can get more from your grazing season.

story: Organisers of the annual Taste of Grampian event at Thainstone have announced this year#s celebrity chefs.At a special launch event Taste of Grampian chairman, John Gregor, revealed that MasterChef star John Torode will headline the th anniversary event on Saturday, June .Chef John said: “I’ve heard the produce in the north-east is some of the best to come out of Scotland.“I’m looking forward to finding some new food and drink producers and using their ingredients in my dishes on the day.”Joining John on the day will be reality TV star Spencer Matthews, who was a surprise finalist in Celebrity MasterChef last year.He will be demonstrating on the day as well as joining John for the main highlight of Taste of Grampian – a joint demonstration.Completing the MasterChef line-up for this year will be Scotland’s national chef, Gary Maclean who was crowned the winner of The Professionals title in .Gary will be demonstrating with Scotch Beef at this year’s eventand supported by Quality Meat Scotlandwho will be the main title sponsor.Also joining the celebrity line-up will be Helen Vass, who was part of the winning team of BBC’s Bake Off Crème de la Crème in . title: the top six questions people are asking google about brexit
story: Heres the answers to your questions:What is the new Brexit Party, which has been supported by Nigel Farage What is the new Brexit Party and how do I join The Brexit Party was launched with the support of ex-UKIP leader Nigel Farage in January and recognised as an official party at the beginning of February . It is a pro-Brexit party. Farage has said he will stand as an MEP under the partythe UK does not leave the EU orArticle  is extended. An official website is coming soon, and you should be able to sign up then, but in the meantime you can search for Brexit Party UK on Facebook.Will my passport be valid after Brexit Theres no need to do anything until your current passport is ready for renewal. British passports will change after we leave the EU, with blue and gold passports making afrom October , but youll still be able to travel on your old burgundy passport until it runs out. If theres a no deal Brexit, youll need to have at least six months left on your passport to travel to an EU country. If you renewed your passport before it expired, then any extra months wont count either - your passport should not be any older than nine years and six months when you travel. What is ERG This stands for the European Research Group, which is a group of pro-Brexit Conservative MPs chaired by Jacob-Res Mogg. It is lobbying on issues surrounding Brexit. The group was in the news as it is expected to rebel against todays House of Commons motion which asks MPs to reiterate its support for renegotiating the controversial Irish backstop.Read more: Will UK workers lose their rights and entitlements after Brexit Will EHIC still be valid At the minute,we fall sick or get injured while visiting the EU, then we can access the same free or discounted medical care that is available to residents of that country. The European Health Insurance Cardproves your eligibility. Regardless of the deal reached, the government will need to renegotiate the reciprocal healthcare arrangements. At the minute, a bill called HealthcareBill is being passed through Parliament to help reach such an arrangement. It is important as the scheme provides healthcare for an estimated , UK expats living in the EU as well as  million UK residents who travel abroad to EEA countries each year Until a new initiative is in place, you should check what the agreement is with the country youre visiting as EHIC may not be valid. Make sure you have travel insurance too .Will I need a visa for my holiday Not for short-term stays for holidays or business purposes. This is providing the UK offers the same deal for EU citizens who want to visit us. We will, however, have to to pay a fee to visit Europe after Brexit. From , youll need to fill in a ETIAS application form so other countries can check youre not a security threat. This is similar to the US ESTA scheme. title: understanding the transition period in the case of a no deal brexit
story: No -there is no deal theres no transition period. What happens to the transition period with an no deal Brexit The transition period was set up as part of the EU Withdrawal Agreement. If this goes ahead, then the transition period would run from March  when we officially leave the EU up until December  .During this period, the UK would trade with the EU in the same way we do now while the two parties agree a new and permanent relationship. It would help businesses, iniduals and the government to prepare for new arrangements and minimise the disruption from any changes. If the withdrawal is rejected, then this is what is being called a no deal Brexit, and there will be no transition period. If this happens, all changes would happen immediately on March .Were getting to the bottom of all your Brexit-related questions. story: The development of Inverurie#s Ury Riverside Park has taken a major step forward with a funding award of over #,.A total of £, was awarded from the LEADER fund, set up to support rural development, and will be used to undertake a wide range of planting within the site.The contract for the planting has been awarded to Aberdeenshire-based CR Contracting North Ltd, which has already done work around the park.Company Director Chris Rogerson said: “We’re really pleased to have been awarded this contract for planting – we also recently constructed the path network, so we are happy to continue with the further development of the park.“Our plan is to complete the path network, then to plant the wet woodland, grassland and wetland meadow areas.“Assuming the weather is favourable we aim to complete the works by winter next year.”The development of the park is managed by a local charity, Ury Riverside Park SCIO.Trustee of the Ury Riverside Park charitable organisation, Claire Maycock, said: “It’s great to see the area develop.“We recently held a volunteer day and planted , trees, so further planting will really enhance the site and make it feel more like a park.”Chair of the Garioch Area Committee, Fergus Hood, added: “This is great news for the Inverurie area, the development of the park is really exciting, and the award of this most recent funding will help move forward with the plans.”European funding programme LEADER allocates cash grants to projects which contribute to key themes identied in Local Development Strategies, such as connectivity, business competitiveness, the environment and people and place.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..!
